name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on the preparation of the special European Council on the dangerous escalation and role of Turkey in the Eastern Mediterranean (2020/2774(RSP)). I would like to point out to Members, as I did yesterday, that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted. The representatives of the Council Presidency and the Council have spoken in favour of this statement, and I would like to give the floor to Minister Michael Roth.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members, Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am honoured to be part of this debate today on this important point too. I am pleased to be able to present to you the priorities of the Special Council of Heads of State or Government of the European Union. In this crisis-ridden time, it is important for the European Union to hold together, to speak with one voice, not to be divided. This is precisely the focus of the German EU Presidency. To make a substantial contribution to strengthening the european Union's weight at international level, because we have a lot of positives to bring in. We all know that authoritarianism is growing, democracy is under pressure worldwide, and it is all the more important that we strengthen and develop our common model, which is based on democracy, diversity, the rule of law and human rights. That is precisely what the Special Council will be about.  We are dealing with difficult players. I want to start with a difficult player: Turkey. The situation in the eastern Mediterranean is highly fragile for many reasons: the situation in the Middle East, the unresolved migration and refugee issues, and then Turkey, which in this region does not live up to the responsibility it actually has to assume, namely to contribute actively to stability and peace. That is why the next European Council must send out a signal that we are fully united in our solidarity with Greece and with Cyprus.  The second important signal that this Council should send out is that we do not need any further escalation now, but that we are contributing to de-escalation. That there can be no military solution to this conflict, but that we want a political solution, and that we make a substantial contribution to this, including in such a way that all options are on the table. The Heads of State or Government will also have to negotiate with Josep Borrell and others on what will happen if Turkey does not fulfil its special responsibilities. Another key player we have discussed and argued about a lot is China. This is particularly complicated because, on the one hand, we see a partner in China. I cannot imagine sustainable climate protection in the world without us having China on board.  We are, of course, also dealing with a competitor in trade and economic policy matters. It should be in our common interest to find a rules-based basis for working closely together on trade and economic issues. But– and this makes it hardest – China is also a systemic rival to us. We have our own social model. Our social model is unthinkable without human rights, without democracy and the rule of law. That is why there must also be an open and constructive exchange on these issues. Just yesterday – in the videoconference – these issues – climate protection, trade, the economy, but also human rights – were addressed accordingly. Honourable Members, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is However, I would also like to draw your attention to other points that I would like to raise here, at least here, because they are also at the heart of the Special Council, because we all know that, due to the fact that in March, the important issues relating to the economy, digitalisation and climate protection had to fall behind.  Just last night, in the context of the own resources debate, we spoke again about the importance of the 'Next Generation EU' development programme. Not only for the crisis-ridden states, but for all of us, because we do not want to build something old, we do not want to follow the conventional, but we want to use this money to promote the socio-ecological transformation of the European Union. The Heads of State or Government will also discuss this. COVID-19 has severely shaken the internal market. However, it must not just be our ambition to restore the internal market. We also want to deepen the internal market, especially with an ambitious industrial strategy. If we really take climate protection seriously, we must also show that we remain competitive on industrial policy issues, that we remain front runners. This will encourage those who say that industry is actually incompatible with ambitious climate protection. We must prove the opposite: climate protection, a sustainable industry, a competitive economy and a strong welfare state fit together. There will be another item on the agenda of the Heads of State or Government, which is the question of strategic Autonomy. We need to improve our resilience. We do not want to override free and fair trade, ladies and gentlemen. However, with the case of products that are central to the safety and health of our citizens, we have said that we also need our own strength, that we need to strengthen European supply chains, and that is what the Heads of State or Government will be talking about. Please see me for pointing out these important points. But they also belong to a strong Europe in the world. This is not only a question of how we define ourselves as other actors, but it is always about our own strength. For us, the issues of climate protection, the sustainable economy and socio-ecological restructuring play a very central role.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: One's own strength includes unity and a strong common foreign and security policy of the European Union. I should now like to give the floor to the Vice-President of the European Commission, Josep Borrell Fontelles.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the subject of our discussion today is the preparation of the special European Council, but focusing on the dangerous escalation and the role of Turkey in the Eastern Mediterranean. That is what I am going to try to do, although as the Presidency of the Council has pointed out, rightly, there are many other issues. Yesterday, we had this important high-level talk with China, and in general, Europe is facing a situation in which we can say that the empires are coming back. The old empires are coming back. There are at least three of them. We can say Russia, China and Turkey, big empires in the past, are coming back with an approach on their immediate neighbourhood and globally, which represents, for us, a new environment. And Turkey is one of these elements that changes our environment.  This debate is very timely. I have to say that tensions have been continuing to rise over the summer. I’ve spent the last few months, including the summer, trying to facilitate de-escalation efforts, but the least I can say is that more efforts are needed; this is the softest way of saying that the situation has not been improving. And the latest move by Turkey to discontinue seismic exploration in the continental shelf of Greece is a step in the right direction and gives us some hope that it will lead to further steps towards dialogue because, as the Presidency said, we are not going to solve it by military means, but through dialogue and negotiations.  European Union and Turkey relations were at the forefront of an extraordinary Foreign Ministers discussion at the meeting that we held in the middle of August, 14 August, and of our Gymnich meeting at the beginning of September, and we will continue next week at Monday’s Foreign Affairs Council and then the European Council at the end of the month.  All that is good and needed because the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean requires urgent and collective engagement. What has been happening during the summer are unacceptable events. Turkey has to refrain from taking unilateral actions and this is a basic element to allow the dialogue to advance, or rather, to start, and the position of the Foreign Affairs Ministers Council has always been very clear: to defend the European Union’s interests and stand in full solidarity with Greece and Cyprus. Immediate de-escalation is essential to allow the resumption of dialogue and negotiation, which is the only path towards stability and lasting solutions.  My colleagues, the European Union Foreign Ministers, were very clear about the possible consequences in the absence of progress in engaging with Turkey, and the European Council will consider this in the light of the most recent developments by the time they meet. There is still some days. The reaching-out continues, hoping that the European Council will be able to develop a constructive approach to our relations with Turkey which are – I can say firmly – at a watershed moment in history. The world will go one side or the other, depending on what’s going to happen in the next few days.  I therefore ask you to support my efforts and the efforts of the Council to create the urgently needed space to work with the Turkish leadership to achieve a de-escalation that will allow the pursuit of lasting solutions to the underlying problems of today’s crisis. Anything else would also undermine the perspective for the resumption of talks on a comprehensive settlement of the Cyprus problem that the United Nations are ready to restart after the election of the Turkish community in Cyprus in October. I’ve been talking with the Secretary-General of the United Nations about it and I think that we need to push for the resumption of these talks. The EU and I, as High Representative, will continue to do everything we can to support the efforts to achieve this comprehensive settlement under United Nations auspices, in accordance with the relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions and in line with the principles on which we have founded our acquis. In terms of domestic developments in Turkey, we perceive a worrying backsliding in the area of rule of law and fundamental freedoms that continues to raise our concerns. We still fail to see Turkey delivering on its promises to take effective measures on a strengthening the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. Turkey’s serious backsliding away from European Union values and reforms and tense relations with several Member States led the Council to decide in 2018 on a stand-still of the accession negotiation and suspension of work on modernising the Customs Union. These were commitments that we took with Turkey under the 2016 agreement, but in 2018 the Council decided to stand still on these negotiations and on suspension of the work on modernising the customs union. With the serious developments in the Eastern Mediterranean and Turkish foreign policy actions in the region since last fall, things have become even more worrying and complex, and as I said, this is a watershed moment in the history of our relations with Turkey.  It’s clear that solutions will not come from an increasingly confrontational relationship. We don’t want it, we don’t look for it. Turkey is an important neighbour for the European Union, and we are not going to change geography. It will remain so. It’s a key partner in many areas, migration, for example. It is going to be difficult to believe that we can solve the migration flows without the help of Turkey both in the Eastern Mediterranean and now with the Libyan crisis in the Central Mediterranean. Turkey is an accession candidate, and a large majority of this population embraces our values and looks to the European Union as a societal model. But it’s clear that the developments in Turkey and Turkey’s action in the Eastern Mediterranean and beyond put into question how our relations will develop in the future, and we have to look for an answer to these questions urgently.  I strongly believe in the need for a solid relationship anchored in a common agenda of partnership that respects mutual interest and is based on values, but this requires us to look at the full relationship in a comprehensive way. I think that this discussion will help us to advance in this direction.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, during the past weeks, we have witnessed an alarming military build-up in the Eastern Mediterranean. All of us are extremely concerned by the very real risk of a direct military confrontation.  Last Thursday, in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), we discussed this dangerous escalation with the Alternate Minister of Foreign Affairs for European Affairs of Greece and the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Turkey. It was a remarkable meeting in several aspects. Listening to the comments of colleagues across party lines, for me four points are very clear. First, de—escalation is urgently needed. Second, we fully support the Council’s clear position of solidarity with our Member States, Greece and Cyprus. Third, we condemn the Turkish drilling activities in the exclusive economic zones of Greece and Cyprus, and we consider them illegal. Fourth, at the next European Council the option of additional sanctions against Turkey must be openly discussed in the light of continued Turkish aggression. This conflict can only be resolved through dialogue and negotiations. I very much hope that the ongoing mediation efforts will bear fruit. But, as the High Representative just underlined, further concrete steps towards creating an environment conducive to dialogue in good faith are needed now.  (Applause)

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, at the meeting to which Mr McAllister referred I ended up asking the Turkish minister to re-examine the sincerity of Turkey's European bet. Because We have offered Turkey the best we have: to be a member of the European Union. And being a candidate means converging in everything: in values, in analysis, in interests—including strategic ones. And yet Turkey diverges throughout the European Union. In all analyses, in all values, in all policies.  I wonder even whether the divergence of the European Union is not becoming a state policy in Turkey and that is why the relationship is completely affected by a lack of trust that leads nowhere. We diverge, of course, into the rule of law, diverge in foreign policy— it is obvious— and diverge into the way we raise issues on the international scale.  Turkey defends its theorists rights with an aggressive, insolent, insulting and contemptuous official discourse towards the European Union, which it claims to claim to join, and now also with an irresponsible display of military force in the Mediterranean. Is it necessary to consider Greece a colony of Europe to defend the rights that Turkey believes it has? Is it necessary to fly over the Turkish soil, I say the soil and not the sea, to defend these ideas?  The diplomatic defence of Turkey's views is buried by this ultranationalist rhetoric for domestic consumption and deepens the gap with the European Union. Mr Borrell's efforts, Germany's efforts, Spain's efforts, too, must be appreciated to disqualify. But Turkey must withdraw its ships from the disputed waters and sit at the table, changing the way it addresses the European Union, because the only way to do so is with diplomatic language appropriate to relations with a country with which, in one format or another, we need to continue to share interests in the future.

name: Malik Azmani
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, anyone following the news knows there are mounting tensions in the Eastern Mediterranean. The situation has become so tense, that a tiny spark could have devastating consequences. The EU must prevent a conflict by being united, constructive, but also by being firm. Threatening a fellow family member with war is not something Renew Europe takes lightly: we will not accept that! it is quite a strong response. On a positive note, Renew Europe suggested last week to the Turkish Foreign Minister to withdraw its research vessel to Turkish waters. This suggested act of goodwill appears to have been honoured: a positive step, one that we applaud! Now we call for an end to the threats, the opening of further dialogue and finding a lasting and sustainable solution to this conflict, possibly via the ICJ in The Hague. We need to de—escalate now. But let me be honest: it is very difficult to see Turkey as an EU candidate member. We need a renewed future relationship with our vital neighbour Turkey.

name: Jérôme Rivière
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr. President, at the time of the first prayer guided by Erdogan in St. Sophia, which has been converted into a mosque, the churches of Greece sounded the death knell. Turkey is not at its first attempt: illegal drilling in the territorial waters of Cyprus, blackmail and extortion with migrants used as bargaining chips and means of pressure on the European Union, objective complacency with jihadism in Syria and Libya, massacre of the Kurds, our allies in the fight against Daesh. On September 5, 40 Turkish tanks positioned themselves along the Evros River, our outer border. Speaking of his Greek neighbour, the Turkish president said: "They will understand that Turkey has the political, economic and military power to tear up the imposed immoral maps and documents". On 30 August, he added: "When it comes to fighting, we will not hesitate to give martyrs." We can't say we didn't know. I solemnly ask the Commission and Parliament to stop bowing to the demands and threats of the Turkish leader. This bid posture leads to the continued negotiation of an accession process with a regime that does not share any of the common values that you gargle at length. A submission that leads to paying the Erdogan regime to keep at home the migrants he himself amassed at our doorstep. A submission that leads to letting Greece defend itself almost alone. Before it is too late, before Turkey commits the irreparable, regain some dignity and courage. Enough with words, deeds! Let us put an immediate end to the customs union, which is costing our countries billions of revenue. Last but not least, let us stop, without detour or false escape, this process of accession which sends only a signal of capitulation in the face of the delusions of this regime with a totalitarian scent. Europeans, wake up!

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing our unconditional solidarity with, and empathy for, our Greek colleagues and their citizens. It is hard to overestimate how it must feel to be threatened by a very aggressive and big, powerful neighbour. At the same time, let’s admit something: this conflict will not be solved by one-sided blaming or bilateral escalation.  The legal claims of neither side are solid enough to convince the world and this Union, nor are the nationalist shouting matches that we witnessed in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) just last week, on both sides. What will solve the problem are four things. First, stop the escalation and return to the status quo ante. Second, start negotiating a comprehensive strategic deal on the Eastern Mediterranean, which will prevent similar conflicts in the future. Third, we should refuse to talk about empires – I refuse to do so. We’re not in Ottoman times and we’re not in the times of the Roman Empire. We should urge our Turkish colleagues to gain more credibility as a foreign power and as a democracy. Without credibility in terms of democracy in Ankara, we will not be able to avoid conflicts in the future. And fourth, and I will end with this, we should extend the Green Deal to the Mediterranean. Stop fighting over fossil fuels of the 19th century! Let’s invest jointly in new green technology in that region too.

name: Εμμανουήλ Φράγκος
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, in recent days, since I started preparing for my speech today and thinking about what I am going to say here, I have realised that my positions are the same as the last time we met, six whole months ago. Conclusion: Nothing has changed, obviously. So let's do a replay to help some people.  It is clear that Turkey does not understand dialogue and logic. So far, it has violated every term of the Lausanne Treaty, which defined its borders, and has demonstrated that, when it sees no reaction, its appetites increase. That is why the European Union must react vigorously. If you want to provoke war, give Turkey support instead of sanctions. We say that heavy economic sanctions now need to be imposed in order to further damage Erdoğan's economy. That's the only way they're going to figure it out. It is, of course, important for the European Union to have people who understand the situation and move honestly in their duty. Unfortunately, Mr Borrell and his colleagues are making the Turkish demands, so that you would think they represent Turkey. I am ashamed that such people represent the European Union, and I hope that the next time we meet this situation has changed.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the conflict in the eastern Mediterranean is a European conflict, and it is in many ways: on issues of European sovereignty, on the misguided EU migration policy and in resolving the Cyprus issue.  Turkey must immediately cease its provocation and military threats and enter a phase of de-escalation and political dialogue. And addressed directly to President Erdogan, who is certainly listening to us very attentively here and now: the Ottoman Empire no longer exists, even if you may not have understood it yet.  In order to enable the conditions for successful dialogue and conflict resolution, Turkey must immediately stop illegal drilling in Greek and Cypriot territorial waters and accept international law and the law of the sea. In order to reinforce this demand, Minister of State, I call on the Member States to impose an immediate halt to arms exports to Turkey.  The EU-Turkey deal, this agreement of shame concluded on the backs of refugees, must be terminated. We finally need a reform of the EU's migration policy that respects asylum and human rights, as the images and events from and in Moria teach us.  The announced Turkish settlement policy in Varosha in Cyprus also hinders a solution to the Cyprus question. Peace talks must be resumed immediately at the level of negotiations reached at the Crans-Montana Cyprus Conference in order to reach a peaceful solution to the Cyprus conflict. And once again, addressed directly to President Erdogan, Turkey can be a permanent partner of the EU – if it achieves a fundamental change in its policy in the eastern Mediterranean.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, the debate on Turkish aggression, which challenges the borders in the Aegean, maintains the occupation of Cyprus and encroachs on the Cypriot EEZ, cannot conceal the responsibilities of the European Union, which maintains a high level of economic, political and military relations with Turkey, and together with the United States and NATO are supporting its aggressive actions in the wider region. Their aim is both to distract Turkey from Russia's influence and to strengthen NATO's south-eastern wing and to co-exploit the Aegean and Eastern Mediterranean for the benefit of the urban classes and American and European monopolies through dangerous competition and haggling against peoples.  These cannot be hidden by resolutions to clarify the role of the European Union. The answer is: a common struggle of the peoples, no change of borders, rejection of the painful arrangements of the United States-NATO-European Union and release from imperialist alliances. Exploitation of marine wealth according to popular needs, with the people in charge of their country.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, being a neighbor doesn't necessarily mean being friends. Friends are respected and helped, neither threatened nor blackmailed. Turkey and Europe are neighbours, but we have long since ceased to be friends.  Twenty years ago a path was opened for Turkey to be part of the European Union, but Erdogan has betrayed our friendship, closed that door and built a wall in front of it. Erdogan likes our money, but he doesn't like our values. If you do not respect the rights of the Turkish people, how do we want them to respect ours? Erdogan has cut off the road to a European Turkey. What is happening in Cyprus, in Lesbos, on the Greek-Turkish border, is an unacceptable tragedy. Those things shouldn't happen in Europe and those things don't happen between friends. That's why I applaud Vice President Schinas' immediate visit in the early days to the Moria camp. Because the migration problem is not a Greek problem, it is a European problem. Turkey has made provocation its instrument to destabilize Europe; not Greece, not Cyprus, to destabilize Europe. Yesterday it was the refugees used as a weapon. Maybe they'll be again tomorrow. Today it is the drilling boats in Greek waters. That is why only a clear message can come out of the next Council for Erdogan: Greece and Cyprus are part of the European family. We're not going to leave them alone, we're going to defend them. We will always be at the negotiating table, but anyone who blackmails, threatens or extorts a country in the European Union must know that it is blackmailing, threatening or extorting us all.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr President, our relations with Turkey are the biggest challenge on the European Union’s external borders at the moment. Illegal drilling activities in the Eastern Mediterranean are the latest layer added to this complex foreign-policy question. Member States have very different policy stances towards Turkey. From finalising trade deals, to calling to completely halt the European Union integration path of Turkey. This would have immense consequences on Turkish citizens that see the European Union as one of the rare possibilities to change their worsening situation for the better. But we cannot remain silent when Turkey as a member of NATO is threatening with casus belli to our Member States and questioning their territorial integrity. Greek and Cypriot borders are our external borders.  We should first and foremost call for a de-escalation of tensions and dialogue. It is clear that in order to allow the dialogue to advance, Turkey has to refrain from unilateral actions. But we must also support the call for further sanctions against Turkey, in the case that Erdoğan continues with this action.  I do hope that leaders can draw common conclusions, also when it comes to defining our policy towards Turkey in general. To conclude, this situation is also a good reminder to continue strengthening the European Defence Union and our common resilience.

name: Nathalie Loiseau (Renew).
text: Mr President, Turkey is a member of NATO and the Council of Europe and a candidate for membership of the European Union. As such, it receives significant EU funding, participates in a customs union with the EU and European research, education or cultural programmes. Europe, which has no responsibility for the causes of the Syrian tragedy, is overwhelmingly supporting Turkey for the reception of millions of refugees on its soil. And yet. The Turkish military presence in Syria, decided without consultation, weakens our fight against Daesh. In Libya, Turkey exports arms and mercenaries in defiance of Security Council resolutions. In the eastern Mediterranean, it threatens and provokes Greece and Cyprus. Within NATO, the record is no better. Ankara has bought Russian military equipment, blocked defense plans for the Baltic states and threatened allied ships. Nor do I want to ignore the human rights violations against countless Turkish citizens. I have a special thought for Ebru Timtik, who died in prison for demanding a fair trial, or for Osman Kavala, who has been detained for more than 1000 days and whose only crime is to love the freedom of the Turkish people more than his own. We represent the European people here. These people believe in respect for international law, respect for human rights and demands respect for respect. Deliberately, the government of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, never short of insults aimed at Europe, turns its back on us. Yes, we want de-escalation in the Mediterranean. Yes, there must be a negotiation, but first and foremost, let us be united behind Greece and Cyprus as much as behind our values.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today is 15 September 2020, and I feel in this House that there is concern about Turkey's behaviour, erdogan's behaviour.  We shouted at this concern, voted for it, urged it with a critical part of the conscience of this House, when EUR 9 billion was given to Turkey, when someone supported the plan to bring Islamic Turkey into Europe.  Well, I wonder why there were no such concerns today. Even when the League, when the opposition in this House, when the critical conscience of this House tried to awaken the conscience of pro-Turkish people in Europe about the 9 billion given in Europe, we were accused of nationalists, fascists, racists, xenophobes, that is, all possible and imaginable adjectives.  So today it is hard to think that it is being taken seriously, that someone is really worried, because, in April, 5 months ago, a funding of 3 billion and 200 million was approved and allocated to Turkey. Five months ago, when someone asked for resources for the COVID-19 emergency, there was no money: for Turkey there was 3 billion and 200 million. When someone was asked to pay more taxes, there was money for Turkey, for the same Turkey that bombed the Kurds, Turkey that was with Islamic extremism, Turkey that is with Haftar, with the Libyan government and dictatorship, which is currently holding Italian workers hostage.  I ask the whole House to help us, I ask President Sassoli, instead of going against me with a ten-day suspension and a EUR 5000 fine for throwing Turkish chocolate to the ground and saying no to Turkey in Europe, I ask President Sassoli and this house as a whole to help us free our fellow citizens. We have Italian workers who are currently being held hostage in Libya: help us to free our workers.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I would like to make it very clear once again: firstly, you have greatly exceeded your speaking time and, secondly, the Rules of Procedure do not allow you to hold up banners in this House. The first time it was very short, but you repeated it all the time. This is contrary to the Rules of Procedure, and I would ask you to never do so again.

name: Mounir Satouri (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the eastern Mediterranean, Turkey and the Member States of the Union are at risk of leading to a military escalation to ensure their exploitation of natural gas. We will not resolve this situation with a simple military tussle. He is showing a new level of unilateralism by seeking to intimidate his own NATO allies and members of the European Union. This conduct is rooted in his exercise of undivided power in Turkey and we must therefore, more than ever, support the Turkish democratic living forces. I condemn Mr Erdogan's unilateralism, but I also regret the object of this dispute. I turn here to all stakeholders: we are going to confront allied countries to exploit non-renewable, polluting resources that accelerate global warming. Natural gas is not our future and it is unfortunate that this impasse is already leading us to such problems with our neighbours. I call for a genuine dialogue with Turkey. The 27 and the Union must stand with Greece and Cyprus and defend a firm but reasoned position on the ecological front and taking into account the needs of all populations.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Mr President, Honourable High Representative, Mr Weber, honourable members, the escalation of tensions in the Mediterranean is a direct consequence of the behaviour and provocations of the Turkish President, Mr Erdogan. This is a direct consequence of his neo-Nazi policy, which is a provocation to the European Union and to our values and to our way of life. Let me remind you that change, the attempt to turn into mosques the sancities of Orthodox Christianity, such as Hagia Sophia, as "Christ the Savior", are actually part of these heavy provocations against us.  And dear colleagues, it is high time to open your eyes and see. I speak here on the left side of the hall, which you are a little duplicitous in terms of the behavior of dictator Erdogan.  Dear colleagues, Turkey at the moment, Erdogan,neo-American Turkey, is not a European country, and we must stop pretending that we do not see this. We must stop pouring European funds there, we must make it clear that at the moment neo-Nazi, Erdogan Turkey is not a European country and cannot be part of the European Union. We must end this hypocrisy and tell each other things as they are. Otherwise, we have an ongoing provocation waiting for us.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, unfortunately the Council has not shown the political will to articulate a resounding response to the Turkish threats, which is why Turkey continues to ignore calls for de-escalation. But Turkish threats are not only directed against Greece, Cyprus or, today, Against France; they are directed against Europe itself. They directly challenge the essence of the principles and the core of its acquis. It is provocative for the European Union to easily impose 'fast track' sanctions against third countries, but at the same time there is no unanimity on strong sanctions against Turkey, which is attacking Europe, because European states continue to maintain strong economic ties with that country, and solidarity ultimately stays in the words.  In the face of this external threat, the European Union must demonstrate that it can form a strong front for the immediate imposition of strong economic sanctions. This is the only way for Turkey to understand that, in the face of its challenges, there is a united, determined Europe. Only in this way will it abandon its aggressive policy, and allow for a real dialogue.

name: Carles Puigdemont i Casamajó (NI).
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, for a long time, Turkish authoritarian leadership has become more and more outspoken. However, the EU has never really dared to criticise its actions. Today, to confront Erdoğan’s escalation in the Eastern Mediterranean, the EU has the responsibility to stay united in front of Turkey’s expansionist actions. All Member States must support both Greece and Cyprus and need to immediately limit their military ties with Ankara and no one should export more arms to them or organise joint naval manoeuvres. It is time for the EU to raise its voice and concerns on the constant harassment of the Kurdish people by Erdoğan’s regime, the constant persecution of independent journalists and the constant jailing of dissidents.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Mr President, international law, and only international law, is the solution to Turkey's problem. The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea was signed in the early 1980s and ratified by 167 states. It's customary law. Every country must comply with the law of the sea, even those that have not signed the Convention, which the Turkish Foreign Minister also accepted in the recent debate we had in the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs.  International law and the law of the sea are not 'a la carte' law, they are not 'a la carte' law, they are not fair with an oriental bazaar. The Convention on the Law of the Sea, in Article 121, refers to islands with economic activity. These islands have their own continental shelf, their own exclusive economic zone, and territorial waters at twelve miles. According to Article 3 of the Convention, Greece has an inalienable right to extend its territorial waters to twelve miles. But Turkey, since 1995, when Greece ratified the Convention on the Law of the Sea, has threatened a "casus belli", i.e. a cause of war, if Greece extends its territorial waters to twelve miles.  Dialogue, then, yes; This is not dialogue; it is blackmailing its neighbours in the Eastern Mediterranean. And this cannot be accepted by either the European Parliament or the European Union.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, Turkey has become a partner in a troublemaker. Its actions have upset the Eastern Mediterranean, and since 1995 it has threatened Greece with a "casus belli", i.e. a cause of war. Yesterday the Turkish Defence Minister, Akar, called for the demilitarisation of the Greek islands; Let's be realistic. There is no European perspective for Turkey. We need a new special relationship that includes both the carrot of upgrading our economic relations and cooperation and the whip of automated sanctions when it tramples on human rights at home or sovereign rights of neighbouring countries. Part of this agreement should also be to provide for joint development of maritime zones under international law with Greece and Cyprus within a limited period of time. Otherwise, with co-promise, we will find a solution to the International Court of Justice in The Hague only on this issue. We need, ladies and gentlemen, a single European strategy. Any crack in our policy merely reinforces the audacity of Turkey and Mr Erdoğan.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I want to thank Mr Borrell especially for his great effort in bridging the tension on both sides and, as already said by my colleague Sergey Lagodinsky, blaming and shaming will not help in resolving this European problem, I would say.  Europe is worried. We all have to be worried about the Eastern Mediterranean. The deepening confrontation in the Aegean, in the waters of Cyprus and Libya, is a very serious sign which would have profound implications for regional stability and NATO. We all have much to lose from an actual conflict. This is a no-win situation. We need a de-escalation immediately. It’s not enough to know that a dialogue based on compromise is the only working solution. I urge both sides to sit at the negotiation table without allowing third countries to take actions that encourage either party. The first positive sign was made, and I am very much looking forward to more comprehensive engagement from the European Union as well.

name: Peter Kofod (ID).
text: Mr President, we are again discussing Turkey. Again, Turkey has gone way over the line, and again dictator Erdogan shows that he is a great danger to Europe, this time Greece and Cyprus. How long is this circus going to go on? I have said it before, and I say it again: stop thinking that you can talk sense with Erdogan! He is not a friend of Europe, he is our enemy. He has calculated that the EU has no intention of doing anything other than holding diplomatic meetings of understanding and drinking dialogue coffee. If the EU wants to get a grip on Erdogan, then you have to treat him like what he is: a bully. Thugs in a schoolyard don't behave any more nicely because the strivers demand them with cream caramels, nor does Erdogan get any friendlier by the fact that you fill his pockets with taxpayers' money. Close the borders with Turkey completely. Make it clear that Turkey must never, ever become a member of the European Union, and close the coffers of Turkey, rather today than tomorrow!

name: François Alfonsi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Mr Erdogan's Turkey is a combination of human rights abuses and violations of international law. On Turkish territory, many elected officials have been stripped of their mandates and replaced in an authoritarian manner by state-imposed governors. For years, MPs and mayors have been imprisoned on imaginary terrorism charges. Many are Kurdish and their terrorism is in fact to claim the rights of the Kurdish people. But it is the entire opposition that Recep Tayyip Erdogan is attacking: it has also been affected by this repression. Outside its borders, Turkey has invaded part of Syria in Kurdish settlement areas. It conducts military operations in Iraq without any mandate that could justify it and, of course- this was widely discussed at the Med7 summit, which brings together the seven Mediterranean countries of the European Union, held in Corsica a week ago - there was the violation of the territorial waters of Greece and Cyprus to seize their gas resources. This aggression was strongly condemned and this summit allowed it. The fact is that the Turkish research vessel and the military fleet that was escorting it returned to their port in Turkey, without the need for a dangerous escalation for peace.  However, all the problems I have mentioned remain as threats to peace and democracy.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I believe that we have a rare situation in this Parliament today and that there is a very broad consensus, which is very good news for High Representative Borrell, but also for the European Council, which has a Parliament almost with the unanimous view that action must be taken in the face of the alarming drift of the Erdogan regime, in the face of what is happening in all areas : in the involution of human rights, in the permanent challenge to the borders of Cyprus and to greece's borders, in harassment, manipulation, use of refugees, and in the already military provocations that are taking place with the issue of drilling as well. In this sense, the time has come for Erdogan to come face, to be told that this drift is impossible, not to continue it, and to see that Turkey cannot behave like one more enemy and be treated as a subsidized friend. This cannot continue like this, we must tell Erdogan that we want collaboration, but that one excludes the other, and you have to tell it in a very strong way, with sanctions.

name: Γιώργος Γεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the Cold War and the old rivalries for the conquest of territories and the sharing of the wealth of the peoples of the region are rekindling in the Eastern Mediterranean. Mr Borrell, let's be honest. It is not just the old empires that are coming back; The protagonist, of course, remains Turkey, with its pirate actions, which violates international law, the law of the sea and the sovereign rights of Cyprus and Greece.  We condemn in the strongest possible way Turkey's new plan for the settlement of Famagusta. The European Union can no longer be cross-country. The European Union shares right-wing and left-wing sanctions, but Turkey caresses it. Clearly, tension must be reduced by sincere action. Oruç Reis left and did not leave. Yavuz and Barbaros, however, continue to be on the Cypriot coast. To have a dialogue but to be honest and honest, with limits, principles and framework, so as to lead to a fair solution to the problems of the peoples of the region, but especially of the Cyprus problem, Mr President, which is the most intense and the most acute.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, war is never necessary or inevitable: an alternative can always be found; it is the way of dialogue and encounter, Pope Francis said. I therefore firmly support the mediation of the German Presidency and the action of the High Representative to stop the escalation of the Mediterranean. Be ware though: mediation does not mean impartiality. That is not possible! Greece and Cyprus, to which I fully support them, are Member States, they are friends and brothers who defend international law, while Turkey is only formally a candidate country that has now renounced all respect for European values, a country that has taken a series of unilateral, provocative, illegal and unacceptable actions.  Too many times I have denounced it over the last six years: what else must happen after what has happened to the Kurds? What else needs to happen after what has happened in the last few days? Yes to the targeted sanctions in order to make Ankara understand that we need to have a constructive dialogue, that it must take a step back from these provocations and that once again, for us, at last, these European values must not only be a slogan but truly indispensable pillars.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, Turkey's criminal activities continue against two Member States of the European Union: Cyprus and Greece. These threats are not only directed against these two Member States but are directed directly against the European Union, since its external borders, sovereign rights and interests are being violated. It is clear once again that Turkey does not understand words, declarations and resolutions. Turkey and Turkish aggression are only thwarted by strict sanctions and measures.  Let me remind you that, despite the international outcry and despite our objections and reactions, overnight they turned the universal symbol of Christianity, Hagia Sophia, into a mosque. Let me remind you that, for 46 years, my country, Cyprus, has been under occupation. And Turkey refuses to withdraw the troops in order to move towards a solution to the Cyprus problem and to enjoy our universal right to return after 46 years to our occupied land and our ancestral homes. Let me remind you that Turkey does not respect any decision, no resolution, no agreement between the European Parliament and the European Union, since it has so far not recognised the Republic of Cyprus. However, apart from reminding you, I must today warn you that my city, the city of Famagusta, is threatened with colonization by the Turks, with the opening of the closed area. And I will ask you, Mr President, and all the political groups to raise the issue of Famagusta at the next plenary session;  Mr President, today we are being watched by 450 million European citizens who want us to take action against Turkey. For me the measures are simple and there are only four: (a) to stop any funding to Turkey — not a single euro to Turkey; (b) to stop the sale of arms to Turkey. It is inconceivable that even one sphere should go from a Member State of the European Union to Turkey, when this sphere will be used against European citizens; (c) to freeze Turkey's customs union; and (d) to ensure sovereign rights and external borders with practical support and practical solidarity from the European Union. Because solidarity is not only words but also works, and that is what we are asking for and entitled to from the European Union.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, let us assume that Turkey does not own 37% of Cyprus, that it does not threaten Greece every day and has not invaded the Aegean. Let us assume that Turkey has not signed an agreement with Libya. Let us assume that Turkey is not blackmailing Europe with immigration. Then I would understand the lukewarm attitude of our partners towards them. As we speak, Oruç Reis went for service and some are celebrating. At the same time, Barbaros and Yavuz are thressing in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. The aim should be de-escalation. Unless strict sanctions are taken against Turkey, all those who behave in the way they behave today will be jointly responsible for its actions.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, it’s good that we will have a special European Council on external affairs in 10 days. We really need it. Look at the world around us –Trump, Putin, Erdoğan, they all challenge the status quo in Europe. Europe stands by and watches, instead of living up to its ambition to become a strong geopolitical actor. Take Turkey, which we are debating today, an EU candidate country. Our relations have been under strain for a long time and not because of the EU’s actions, but because of Turkey’s actions. Yes, we need to stay on speaking terms, but let’s be honest and acknowledge that this Turkey cannot join Europe. We need to stop the accession negotiations and build a strong, new partnership with Turkey. This should be our message ahead of the special European Council. (Applause)

name: Roman Haider (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not understand at all that Turkey is still a candidate for membership of the EU.  It is also incomprehensible to me in principle that an Asian state can be a candidate for accession to the EU. It is also completely incomprehensible that a state that threatens another EU state with war can be a candidate country. And it is absolutely incomprehensible that this oriental despotism is not only sponsored by the EU with billions of euros by means of so-called pre-accession aid, but can also blackmail the EU. Now that two EU members are directly threatened with war, where is it now, the European, the much-vaunted European solidarity? The EU is cautious about this. Serious, painful sanctions against this politrabauken on the Bosphorus are unfortunately being used here to make a wide arc in the EU. This is sad, because this cuddly course will hardly impress this self-proclaimed sultan. Where the EU is called upon to show strength, it fails. That is sad.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Turkey is an important strategic partner for the EU, both economically and geopolitically, but that does not negate its many misdemeanours: backsliding democracy and human rights; devastating actions in Syria and Libya; disregard of international law with regard to Greece and Cyprus; lack of respect for Christian communities. And this is not the first, second, third or even fourth time we’ve had this exact same debate in this Parliament. Turkey has not presented itself as a worthy candidate country for years. We need a fundamental strategic rethink of our relationship. It’s time the EU accepts that at best we can only have a business relationship with Turkey. Accession negotiations should be stopped and the budget allocation also for this process should be put to better use. We need the money for other things. Trying to turn Erdoğan into a reliable and cooperative partner is like trying to flog a dead horse. I don’t want to do that.

name: Özlem Demirel (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The militarised foreign policy of the Erdogan regime must, of course, be condemned. But this conflict is not about Erdogan. Here he even has popular support.  The fact is, well-known disputes are rekindled because of the many gas. The fact is, there are many players in the eastern Mediterranean: international oil companies are trying to secure their shares. But instead of yielding to the desire of Exxon Mobile, ENI, or Total, fair, sustainable political solutions should be found – also central to the Cyprus issue, by the way.  But Mr Roth, calling on Turkey to de-escalate and at the same time exporting warships from Germany is not credible. But it is also a fact that France is currently selling a large number of war equipment to Greece.  Ladies and gentlemen, sabre-rattling will not bring a solution. Let us stop serving the interests of arms and oil companies and let us make lasting peace in the interests of the people of Europe, Turkey and Greece.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: Mr President, with the pandemic and its health, economic and social consequences, there has been much discussion in our European european solidarity institutions. However, it is time, and it is urgent, for this solidarity to apply unconditionally and resolutely to our Greek and Cypriot Member States. In the eastern Mediterranean, there is no hesitation to have. Without a fundamental and essential reminder of this vital principle for the European Union, which is solidarity, we will not achieve de-escalation and dialogue because, of course, it is dialogue and negotiation that will resolve these long and numerous disputes between the Member States and Turkey. However, we must not be under any illusions: in order to engage in a dialogue in good faith, we must first be able to support the balance of power of the provocateurs and support The verbal and military balance of power of Mr Erdogan, it is to show our capacities and our solidarity. From this point of view, beware of the ambiguity surrounding the concept of mediation of the European Union. The European Union is not a mediator in this crisis: it must support de-escalation and dialogue, but it remains an actor alongside all its Member States.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Union's relationship with Turkey is once again being put to the test and, once again, by unilateral provocative actions by the Turkish Government. There are many examples that could be cited, from incidents at land borders to the disregard for the rule of law and now the very serious intervention in the exclusive maritime areas of two Member States.  How long will this type of behaviour by a candidate state that is a partner member in NATO be tolerated? It's time to be clear. Several red lines have already been crossed. It is therefore imperative to move towards an arms embargo and strengthen the lists of targeted sanctions. We must maintain support for Turkish civil society, which is also the victim of Mr Erdogan's totalitarian dismantling. We must keep diplomatic channels of dialogue open, but these incidents cannot be ignored. Erdogan has to realize that the behavior swelled in recent weeks and his strategy of destabilization in general will not go unanswered. The attacks on Greece and Cyprus are attacks on the European Union.

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou (Renew).
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, we are meeting today to discuss Turkey's role once again, instead of answering the following questions: what is the role of the European Union in the Eastern Mediterranean? What is our foreign policy vis-à-vis Turkey? For too long, the Turkish President has been playing the cat-and-mouse game with Europe. Syria, Libya, illegal drilling... Ambiguity must be put to an end. Some say that the day before yesterday, he withdrew his Turkish ship from Greek waters. Is that enough? Can we trust him? Ladies and gentlemen, the recovery plan was born from the health crisis, a sign of a mature Europe that wants to avoid the mistakes of the past. From this political crisis will also have to be born a common diplomacy to ensure our security and protect our European sovereignty. As the President of the French Republic has said, we must build this Mediterranea pax, not only with words, but with deeds.  The fate of Europe, ladies and gentlemen, is linked to the fate of the Mediterranean. There is an urgent need for the European Union and its policies to assert themselves.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: – Mr President, yesterday evening we all got an email from the Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs to our mailing list with some explanations and proof of its rights. In the last sentence of the letter, they say, ‘As a candidate country, we expect the EU and the European Parliament to maintain an equal distance to the parties.’ First of all, I think 99% of this House agrees on one thing today: Turkey will never be part of the EU, part of Europe. Our histories are too different. Our religions are too different. Our ideologies are too different. That’s why I have a question for Mr Borrell. As you have seen today, we all agree on one thing. For how much longer will we give the Turkish side the opportunity to say ‘as a candidate country’? Just take it away. It stops. We know very well that at least Greece, France, Estonia and many other countries will never accept the idea of Turkey in the EU. We will never accept spending our taxpayers’ money and billions on Turkey while it supports mosques and radical Islam in the EU. Can you say when it will be possible to say it is no longer a candidate country of the EU?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Wiseler-Lima, I must now briefly suspend the sitting for the start of the first round of voting, and then you will be at your word.  Therefore, before we proceed with the debate, I must open the first round of voting today. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round is open from 10.30 a.m. to 11.45 a.m. The voting procedure you are already familiar with is being applied. All votes today are roll-call votes and both Members of the European Parliament and citizens can check the vote and the results of the vote on the basis of the document published on the plenary session's website.  I therefore declare the first round of voting today open. You can vote until 11.45 a.m. We will announce the outcome of this round of voting at 2.15 p.m. this afternoon.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the statement by the Council and the Commission in preparation for the special European Council on the dangerous escalation and role of Turkey in the Eastern Mediterranean (2020/2774 (RSP).

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Mr President, Turkey has the status of a candidate country for membership of the European Union. It is a member of the customs union of the European Union and NATO. In addition, whole sections of Turkish civil society aspire to the values promoted within the European Union. The current government is thus challenged from within for its constant deviations from democratic values and fundamental freedoms: annulment of the results of elections won by the opposition; intimidation and imprisonment, including of journalists. There is thus a civil society that is militant, eager to see human rights respected, and looks to the European Union with hope. For the current government, establishing a bellicose relationship with the European Union is a way of making it an adversary, a role we refuse towards the Turkish people. The attitude of the Turkish authorities in the Mediterranean is a pure provocation: a regular violation of Greek airspace and territorial waters with no apparent purpose, disputed waters where no natural resources have been discovered. I ask you: what is this Turkish power really looking for? We call for strong measures against these provocations and continue to assure our Turkish friends, defenders of fundamental rights, of our support.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about Erdogan's actions, we are sadly used to using harsh words. However, what is happening in the eastern Mediterranean goes far beyond all limits, with Ankara coming to directly threaten Athens after months and months of illegal drilling and agreements contrary to international law, such as the Memorandum of Understanding with Libya on the delimitation of maritime jurisdictions. Erdogan has one thing clear: when he threatens Greece or Cyprus, he is not simply threatening his neighbours, with Brussels as a mediator. It is threatening the whole of the European Union. And as Europe we must react together, keeping a channel of dialogue open, working towards de-escalation, of course, but next week's extraordinary European Council is signaling a strong signal, with a package of sanctions, but also with an embargo on the sale of arms to a country which, in addition to openly violating international law and jeopardising relations within NATO itself. , continues to decline in respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and democracy.  It is time for Europe to pursue its own policy in the Mediterranean without being crushed by blackmail by autocrats such as President Erdogan.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In my youth, Turkey was a military regime fought by all leftists and the pariah of international society, but it was a secular regime. Today, the situation in Turkey is much worse than it was then, especially as regards the situation of ethnic and religious minorities or women. Otherwise, there is no freedom of the press, freedom of expression and the rule of law. We know that, and we discuss it again and again, and nothing happens.  Now Turkey is even threatening two full members of the EU with military action, and nothing is still happening. We are debating here, but I continue to hear from the left that we need more dialogue and de-escalation.  De-escalation, dear leftists, is another word for betrayal of European values. That is why I am in favour of finally ending the dialogue and no longer de-escalating it, but escalating it, namely escalating in the spirit of European values, and finally enforcing these European values – including in relation to Turkey.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we should not need to remind ourselves that Greek and Cypriot borders are European borders – European Union borders. When Russia invaded Georgia, the Donbass in Ukraine, and Crimea, all the European Union reacted because Russia was not respecting international law or international borders. Now that we have this constant bullying at our own European borders, are we going to be silent? Are we going to be inactive? Aren’t we going to do something? Turkey is not a third country. It has a customs union. It is a candidate country and a member of NATO, and so it has obligations that other countries don’t have. We therefore have to be firm and clear. It’s European borders that are at stake. (Applause)

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Where the arguments are snout, there is a threat of violence options for some. There's Erdoğan right now. In an increasingly uncertain world, we need more dialogue, not escalation. We need more understanding, not polarization. But I have to say that, after last week's meeting of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I almost lost hope.  The fact that Turkey's Foreign Minister, Cavusoglu, feels compelled to say at the meeting that he is proud of his ancestors, the Ottomans, and that the EU's borders do not end after Cyprus and Greece makes me wonder, on the one hand, whether he knows what the Ottomans were doing and, on the other, how well he can read a map. Believe me, I too wish Turkey was at a point where there was hope for EU membership. It would mean that all the peoples – Turks, Kurds, Syrians, Assyrians, Armenians, Alevis and everyone else – in Turkey lived in democracy and freedom, that the occupation of Cyprus was history, and that the conflict with Greece was resolved. Unfortunately, however, we are not there yet, and with the Erdoğan government it is completely impossible. Now, if ever, it is time for sanctions against Erdoğan and his lackeys.

name: Isabella Tovaglieri (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to extend Islamic hegemony over the eastern Mediterranean, President Erdogan does not miss an opportunity to threaten the European Union and to challenge its economic interests and cultural values. In July, in fact, in an act of open hostility towards Europe's Christian roots, it converted Istanbul's Hagia Sophia into a mosque. In August, however, it deployed 25 warships to survey deposits around Cyprus and the Greek islands, attacking Athens' fleet, which defended its exclusive economic zones. It is clear that we can no longer tolerate these provocations. President Macron, although seriously threatened by Ankara, did not hesitate to act with words and deeds, aware that the escalation desired by Erdogan, could have dangerous consequences for all Mediterranean countries. Instead, the Conte government stammers undecidedly about what to do, increasingly succumbed to dictators and increasingly on the fringes of international politics, obviously occupied more to welcome illegal immigrants than to protect the security of The Italian coasts and the borders of Europe, borders that, as far as we are concerned, Turkey will never have to cross.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, we have an enormous responsibility that derives from the knowledge that it is not at all true that Turkey cannot be stopped.  The problem is that Europe is not stopping it: in both Syria and Libya, Russia has actually taken on this task. So what's our emergency? Returning as Europeans to defend the Mediterranean and today the threat is Turkey.  How can we achieve this? One proposal may be the establishment of a European Union special envoy for the Eastern Mediterranean, with the aim, on the one hand, of resolving legal disputes over the law of the sea and, on the other, of guaranteeing a peace marked Europe, because Turkey's peace with us, and therefore towards Greece and Cyprus in particular, is not a provocation. , in fact, a neo-Ottoman strategy, the victim of which is the Greek, Latin and Christian history of Europe.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D).
text: Mr President, in the Eastern Mediterranean there is another episode of a chronic crisis that has simply been exacerbated by Erdoğan's hegemonic ambitions to fill the void left by America's absence and the now short-circuited NATO, until at least the European Union has come of age in its foreign policy, finally taking a leading role in the wider Mediterranean region and perhaps, Mr Representative, by entrusting a special European representative for the Eastern Mediterranean with consultation at all levels with Turkey in favour of peaceful coexistence with the European Union.  Let me underline here the obvious: that respect for international law and the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus are non-negotiable and do not come on anyone's table. Europe must therefore put an end to Erdoğan's neo-Ottoman geopolitical conquests — because Greece and Cyprus are Europe — by stopping using double standards, depending on the economic and armament interests of some Member States, and finally acquiring a strong and long-term strategy, from Libya to Syria, on our wider borders.

name: Tom Vandendriessche (ID).
text: At the beginning of March, tens of thousands of migrants, mostly young men of military age, laid siege to the Greek border. Sultan Erdogan used mass migration as a blackmail tool to detach more money for his regime. There was hardly any reaction. Erdogan has known since then how weak and indecisive the European Union is. Today, his regime is violating Greece's territorial waters and airspace. Once again, there is a hesitantness to intervene decisively. Apeasement doesn't work with these kinds of leaders. We must get erdogan's regime to its knees or we must remain at the mercy of Turkish blackmail and aggression. Therefore, stop the billions for Turkey. Abolish the customs union and announce economic sanctions. And above all: finally stop the accession talks to the European Union, because Turkey is and will never be a part of Europe geographically religiously, culturally and historically.

name: Άννα-Μισέλ Ασημακοπούλου (PPE).
text: Mr President, in politics there are times when you have to choose whose side you're on. In the case of Turkish threats, blackmail, provocation, flagrant violation of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, but also of international law, it goes without saying that the European Union will take the side of its Member States; , statements, statements. Statements of solidarity and support and statements that push us to de-escalation and dialogue. And, don't get me wrong, statements are welcome; Because, as our Prime Minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, said, "the challenges stop, the discussions begin". But in politics, in the end, you are judged not by the statements but by the result. It is obvious that Mr Erdoğan does not take words. That is why I am asking you today to send a clear message to the summit that, as far as Turkey is concerned, it is time to finally move on from declarations to sanctions.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, I quote a few key facts — I stress the word 'facts' — about turkey's behaviour, which we as the European Union unequivocally accept. Turkey has already violated the sovereignty and sovereign rights of two Member States of the European Union: Greece and Cyprus. But, especially in relation to Cyprus, it does not simply threaten; it has already invaded its exclusive economic zone and has held, since 1974, the northern part of the Republic of Cyprus. Turkey has invaded Syria. He has intervened in Libya and Iraq. What has brought us here, then, is the impunity of the criminal; Because we have tools: sanctions, a ban on arms sales and a suspension of the customs union that concerns Turkey's huge export sector. The latter has been proposed in cases other than the European Union; And one final appeal to you, my dear Mr Borrell, and to the German Presidency: The neo-Ottoman monster does not deal with it with dialogue; first you punish it and then you negotiate.

name: Λουκάς Φουρλάς (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, it has already taken too long to put the brakes on the uncontrolled and provocative behaviour of criminal Erdoğan and his gang. You have seen when Turkey goes into dialogue: now, under the threat of measures. But we are too late and we have given it the right, Mr Borrell, to threaten two Member States every day with war. I do not think there is anyone here who does not argue that it is now necessary to impose measures on Turkey. From this Chamber we must send the message to the fascist Erdoğan, who oppresses even his own people, that the European Union is here, not threatened and not blackmailed. It is time to prove that this family, our European family, stands up and supports partners in practice, not just in words. Above interests puts law, principles and values. As we treat every Lukašenko, we also treat Erdoğan.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr Borrell, the European Parliament is clearly largely dedicated to the European message of solidarity and to seeking a solution for, however, de-escalation rather than escalation on the ground. Geopolitical objectives and facts destabilise the situation in the region and we MEPs must stand strongly behind our European values, but in a spirit of partnership and peace.  The border with Turkey is europe's border, it's been heard several times, and we need to know how to preserve it. However, we need dialogue to calm tensions, but dialogue cannot be successful if it is based on blackmail. The territorial integrity of each Member State must be protected. We need to build bridges, we can't tear them down.  We must warn our strategic partners that there is a spirit of European values, but insisting on respect for land, sea and airspace, as well as the application of international law. I think Turkey heard our messages, we'll see the answer.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President. I wish to thank Members for all their contributions to the analysis of the situation and the proposal for the next Foreign Affairs Council and the next European Council. I will consider all these comprehensive views and I will share them with my colleagues at the Foreign Affairs Council and transmit them to the members of the European Union when the heads of state and government meet. I have the honour and the responsibility to attend the European Council meeting, and I will transmit the positions of the European Parliament which have been expressed today.  It is clear to me that we have to stand by our interests and demonstrate our readiness to protect the rights and interests of the European Union and especially the ones of Cyprus and Greece, which has been threatened. In our Gymnich meeting in Berlin we got a political agreement and now we are trying to make this particular agreement become a decision, a formal decision at the Foreign Affairs Council. The working group at the Council are engaged on that. Unhappily, today there is no agreement. You know that sanctions require strong agreements between Member States, unanimity in some cases, and this for the time being is not the case. We will continue working in order to find a solution that could make possible both sanctions on Belarus and sanctions on Turkey, to follow the same base as we agreed in the informal meeting in Berlin.  But, at the same time, it has also been expressed here that a minimum of trust and dialogue with Turkey has to be pursued in order to stop the escalation. I do think both things are contradictory. We have on the one hand to show our readiness and our stance, and on the other to continue talking. This is the work of diplomacy and that we are trying to do, especially I myself with the help of the External Action Service – to look for ways to work through our problems and improve our relations. I cannot answer all the questions that you have been raising.  I would only like to say to Mr Lagodinsky and others that I share very much their approach to try to substitute the search for energy in those seas, which is something that we know that it is not exactly in accordance with our Green Deal, and instead of that we should try to provide to Cyprus, Turkey and the Greek islands big support in order to develop alternatives energies. The sun is there. The wind is there. All the natural resources that we want to mobilise in order to provide cleaner and decarbonised energy are there. I think that one of the ways to try to solve the problem is that we would like to stop looking for carbon energies – and although gas is a ‘less—carbon’ one it is still a carbon one – and to look for another solution. This will be part of the solution. At the same time, you claim here decisions that are outside my capacity and the capacity of the Council. Like, for example, the arms issue. it is a matter for the Member States and all of you can influence the attitude of your Member States through the national parliaments. I’m sure that the voices that have been expressed here at the European Parliament will also be heard at the national parliaments, and the political parties that you represent will ask at national level the same thing that you have been asking, here because the answer has to come from Member States. The European Union has not the capacity, for example, to decide an arms embargo. it is a unilateral decision of the Member States to decide what to do with their arms policy. About the resources that we have been providing to Turkey, as some have been mentioning, I want to make the difference between the resources that we allocate to Turkey and the resources that we allocate to help Syrian and other refugees being hosted by Turkey. These are different things. This money goes to provide schools and health care and social security, and even food, for hundreds of thousands of the refugees that are in Turkey. So the money in some cases goes through the Turkish Government, but in most of the cases it goes directly to the interested people through NGOs and through United Nations organisations. I suppose that everybody here will be in favour of giving financial support to alleviate the situation of the refugees being hosted in Turkey. Please make the difference, because these are completely different things. Thank you very much for all your contributions. I understand that there are strong feelings about the Turkey issue, Turkish membership. Our relations with Turkey are, as I said, at a watershed moment. It is one of those moments in history where decision—makers have to go and face difficult decisions, trying to look for the best for all of us. I am sure that this is what the European Union Council will try to do at the next meeting. (Applause)

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members, High Representative, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. There are two messages coming out of this important debate here in Parliament. The first is addressed to Ankara: President Erdogan, stop this policy of aggression, military escalation. They will not succeed.  The second important message is addressed to our partners in Greece and Cyprus. They are not alone in this fire-hazardous confrontation. We are at your side and we are doing everything we can to return to political dialogue. I have great sympathy for the emotionality that has been expressed here in many speeches. But on one point I am a little surprised. The European Union is committed to peace and dialogue. I do not know whether it will help us to continue to turn the rhetorical spiral of escalation. Nor do I understand how this can give the impression, ladies and gentlemen, that we are doing nothing but talking. But without talks, everything else is nothing. And when it is said here that we are constantly throwing new money in Turkey's throat, I would like to express my support for the High Representative. We have recalibrated the pre-accession funds. The money we are making available to Turkey goes primarily to where it is urgently needed: to the critical part of Turkish civil society in its efforts to strengthen democracy and the rule of law and human rights. And I fully support this policy. And it is just as the High Representative has just said: Turkey has taken in four million refugees. I am responsible for your assessment of whether there or in the European Union the refugees are treated better.  And I have the impression that the money that the European Union is making available to Turkey to improve the situation of refugees, to create jobs, to improve education, is well-invested money. We need not be ashamed of this at all. And if we get the impression that we are not doing anything here any more, I would like to point out that the negotiations on deepening the customs union are on hold, just as the accession negotiations with Turkey are on hold.  But please, let us not forget one thing: Turkey is not just made up of Mr Erdogan. We have a critical civil society there, which is still looking towards the European Union. It is a divided society. And I accept every argument in favour of Turkey: regression, massive regression in the rule of law, in freedom of the media, in freedom of expression, in the independence of the judiciary. However, I do not accept one argument, honourable Members: religion must not play a role in the assessment of Turkey, at least not in the European Union. We are a community based on religious freedom. We are not an exclusive club of just one religion. Millions of people of Muslim faith live here in the European Union, so this must not be an argument directed against Turkey. There are many other arguments.  In this respect, I would like to reassure you – and I am grateful for the important contributions – that the President-in-Office of the Council, but also the Presidency of the Council, the German Presidency, will work tirelessly to resolve this conflict. And I am very pleased that we can count on your support.

name: Der Präsident. –
