text: Finally, I would like to thank both Speakers from the Commission and the Council for responding to our contributions to the debate and for having the differentiated and determined approach to drawing the right conclusions from them. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Wednesday, 16 September 2020, and the final vote will take place on Thursday 17 September 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Guido Reil (ID)
text: Writing. – Turkey has repeatedly threatened some EU Member States in recent days. It is always about gas in the Mediterranean, migration and, or Cyprus. The EU Parliament rejects these threats as "unacceptable" for an EU candidate country. Unacceptable? I find the EU's action unacceptable. Why is Turkey still a candidate for EU membership? What else has to happen? Does Turkey have to officially declare war on Greece? The accession negotiations have failed. The billions of euros that we have paid to Turkey as aid for accession have been soured. We can write them off. We are only having sham negotiations. We should end this theatre as soon as possible and finally take note of reality. From 2007 to 2020, we paid turkey a total of around EUR 10 billion. The money is gone. If we believe that Erdogan is changing course simply because we are giving him a few billion, then we are naive and cling to fiction. Turkey handles 30% of its international trade with Germany. We should point out our market power in order to assert our interests in relation to Erdogan. Instead, our Chancellor is being blackmailed by this would-be sultan with a half-cooked "refugee deal."

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE)
text: Writing. – Turkey's offending stance in the Aegean and eastern Mediterranean is ongoing and escalating. The withdrawal of the Turkish research vessel from the Greek continental shelf does not signal a de-escalation of tension, as the Turkish fleet remains in the region, and top Turkish government officials continue the provocative rhetoric, stressing that Oruç Reis will return after its repair. President Erdoğan is citing pre-formal dialogue to buy time ahead of next week's European summit. It seeks to blackmail a political agenda that directly offends international law and Greece's sovereign rights, disregards our decisions and European institutions and intensifies Turkish revisionism. The only way for Turkey to realise that it needs to change policy is to impose severe economic sanctions on it that affect the core of its economy, such as the suspension of the favourable terms of the customs union. Otherwise, if the European Union once again backs down on Turkey's illegal, blackmailing and provocative revisionist policy, this will be interpreted as the weakness of a strong Europe, which has 500 million citizens but cannot enforce its decisions. It is insulting to the Union that economic agreements outweigh principles and values and undermine its unity.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is good that the period of illusions about the future of our relations with Turkey has passed idly by. This summer it has been clearly demonstrated that Turkey poses a threat not only to Greece and Cyprus but to the whole of Europe. Contrary to every principle of international law, it provocatively violates the sovereign rights of the countries of the Eastern Mediterranean region and with threats and bullying is blackmailingly trying to create fait accompli in the region. Greece, for its part, has done and will continue to do the obvious. Defend its legal rights and resolutely guard the EU's borders. Now it is the EU's turn to rise to the occasion and respond decisively to Turkey's provocative and offensive behaviour, starting with immediate and harsh trade and economic sanctions. The defence of European borders and international law is neither a negotiated nor a bilateral problem of a Member State. I call on you to rise to the occasion so that we can put an end to Turkey's dangerous games together. I'm sure we can and will.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the statements by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, on the situation in Belarus (2020/2779(RSP)), on the situation in Lebanon (2020/2775(RSP)) and on the situation in Russia and the poison attack on Alexei Navalny (2020/2777(RSP)). I would like to point out once again that this debate does not accept spontaneous speeches and blue cards. Once again, I would like to give the floor to the High Representative and Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Josep Borrell Fontelles, on this joint debate on these important issues of day-to-day politics and principle.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, you have invited me to address the plenary on three very important issues. Altogether, the three of them are going to be a lot of work and we do not have enough time to deal with them as much as needed, but let’s try to summarise what has indeed been a summer of crisis.  Let us start with Belarus. You know, the situation is clear for us. We consider the elections on 9 August fraudulent. (Interruption from the floor). So we don’t recognise Lukashenko as the legitimate president of Belarus and I appreciate the support that this Parliament has demonstrated for the rights of the Belarusian people, as well as the actions taken until now by the European Union.  But the brutal crackdown continues. More than 7 500 peaceful protesters have been detained, 500 cases of torture have been recorded and documented. All Presidium members of the Coordination Council have been arrested or forced into exile, with the exception of the Nobel Prize Laureate Ms Alexievich.  We have reacted. We have reacted across four pillars of action. First, by adopting sanctions. We are in the process of adopting sanctions for a substantial number of those responsible for the violence, repression and falsification of election results. They are right now under examination by the Council working parties, with a view to adoption as soon as possible. As soon as possible – what does this mean? They should be adopted before the European Council. We want to keep European credibility. We are trying to apply a gradual approach and if the situation further deteriorates, additional sanctions will be envisaged. Secondly, we call on the Belarusian authorities to find a way out of the crisis by ending the violence and unlawful detentions and by establishing an inclusive national dialogue. We continue to stress that we are ready to support any credible initiative in this direction. For example, the offer of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) Chair—in—Office to visit Minsk. It could help to resolve the crisis. But we stress the fact that, from our point of view, the re-run of the elections under OSCE supervision would be the best solution, but so far, it has been impossible for us to reach out to the Belarus authorities at any level.  The single-minded determination of Lukashenko to stay in power with the apparently increasing support of Moscow makes all this difficult. You know that there was a meeting between Lukashenko and Putin on Monday, yesterday, and it seems from this meeting that support by Russia for Belarus, for Lukashenko, continues.  Thirdly, we are committed to strengthening our engagement with the Belarusian people and civil society. President von der Leyen announced EUR 53 million allocated to Belarus, funds which have immediately been made available to the victims of violence, and we are trying to provide support to the independent media.  And finally, we are conducting a review of EU-Belarus relations. We are identifying areas where contact should be suspended or scaled back, areas where it is in our interest to engage and even intensify contacts in support of the Belarusian people and civil society, and finally areas where we can assist further if there is a move towards a new democratic Belarus. I want to stress these three areas: where we can suspend or scale back, where we can engage and where we can further assist. This is telegraphically what I can say about the Belarusian situation.  Let’s now focus, as you have requested, on the difficult situation in Lebanon. As you know, there was a devastating explosion on 4 August in Beirut that struck the country in the financial, economic and political dimension. The situation is compounded by the pandemic, and the consequences of the conflict in Syria, including the fact that Lebanon has been hosting over a million Syrian refugees for many years now. Last week, additionally, we witnessed a huge fire in the port of Beirut.  I am proud to say that our response to the explosion was swift and solid. We mobilised civil protection and immediate humanitarian and crisis response in the amount of EUR 63 million. Our civil protection mechanism mobilised 17 Member States, plus Norway and Turkey, with search and rescue teams and medical care providing substantial life-saving assistance.  Our determination is strong and clear. The European Union is a long-standing partner and a major donor of humanitarian, development and other assistance to Lebanon, and we remain committed to assisting the Lebanese people in the upcoming period. Going forward, and as called for by President Macron during his visit of 1 September, we want to quickly see the formation of a capable, representative and accountable Lebanese government. It should deliver on a credible reform agenda, as the Lebanese people have long been claiming. Concrete steps to reform the financial system and to adopt anti-corruption measures remain vital. As important are the necessary reform of the electricity sector and public procurement. Lebanon needs also to reach agreement with the International Monetary Fund in order to solve its deep economic crisis. It is also a precondition for a possible macro-financial assistance programme from the EU. We cannot do that without, first, an agreement with the International Monetary Fund. But we have recently finalised with the World Bank and the United Nations a joint rapid damage and needs assessment for rehabilitation and reconstruction, and work continues on its operationalisation  This should help to provide assistance in the future and we will continue to apply safeguards to ensure that funds reach the intended beneficiaries. That’s what the people of Lebanon asked, to give the help directly to the people in need. They do not seem to rely very much on or trust a lot their institutions and government.  And finally, an independent and credible investigation into the explosion should be conducted and we stand ready to help. We want to help Lebanon, but Lebanon must also do its part and proceed urgently to implement long-standing reform.  And now, let’s have a look at the situation, as you have requested, in Russia, and particularly the poisoning of the Opposition Leader Mr Alexei Navalny, which has shocked all of us. I would like to take this opportunity to transmit, once again, my best wishes to him and his family, and the fact that we condemn in the strongest possible terms this assassination attempt. Because this is the word we have to use: assassination attempt. I personally issued two statements immediately after this event happened, on 24 August and 2 September, and the EU 27 issued a declaration on 3 September.  The German Government confirmed on 2 September that Mr Navalny was poisoned by a military chemical and yesterday we learned that French and Swedish laboratories have ratified this conclusion. There is now irrefutable evidence that a nerve agent from the Novichok group, similar to the one used in the assassination attempt on Sergei and also on Yulia Skripal in March 2018, was used to try to assassinate Mr Navalny.  The use of chemical weapons by anyone, anywhere, and at any time and under any circumstances constitutes a serious breach of international law and international human rights standards. So we will keep calling upon the Russian authorities to cooperate fully in this investigation and particularly with the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.  This is all I have to inform you of and I am looking forward to hearing your contribution to these three very important issues of our foreign policy.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I admire the people who stand up peacefully but resolutely against the electoral fraud of the old regime in Belarus. They deserve our support. We, too, do not recognise this choice. We too are calling for new elections. We too call for a dialogue between the regime and the Coordinating Council.  Svetlana Tichanovskaya is legitimized by the electorate to negotiate how to shape the way to new elections. We too call for an end to the violence of the KGB, the Omon troops and the police against the peaceful citizens. We also call for the immediate release of all demonstrators and political prisoners, such as Kolesnikova, Tichanovsky, Babaryko, Sevyarynez, Vlasova, Snak, Dylevsky.  We too demand that there should be no foreign intervention so that the Belarusians can shape their democratic revolution according to their wishes. But Russia is also foreign, Mr Putin. The Brezhnev Doctrine has ended up in the dustbin of history with the Paris Charter and the end of the Warsaw Pact. I call on the Russian President, for once, to accept the will of a people. A people that has not developed any anti-Russian feelings. Take advantage of that! Support the will of the people and gain influence, and not through violence, occupation, oppression, intimidation and troll propaganda!  And I call on the Council and the Commission: let us base our policy towards Belarus on the wishes and expectations of the people there and not on Mr Putin's wishes. For the period after the victory of the democratic revolution, we should have a substantial aid package in place for Belarus, which supports political, economic and social development. The only condition should be that this government has emerged from free, democratic elections. Anything else is a matter for the Belarusians. We accept the way, we do not send tanks or green males under any circumstances. We can guarantee that. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, neither the thousands of arrests made since the fraudulent elections on 9 August against protesters, opposition leaders, workers, students and journalists, nor the hundreds of allegations of torture in detention centres have frightened a population that considers Lukashenko's dictatorship to be Belarus's main problem.  Mr Borrell, you can count on the commitment of the Social Democratic family to accompany the Belarusian people on their way to democracy and freedom. We are aware that the solution is not only what happens in Minsk, but also in Moscow. And we are committed to the aspirations of the political opposition as a whole, embodied by the Coordination Council. A peaceful transition, the release of political prisoners and the holding of a new election.  The work of Tijanóvskaya, Tsepkalo and Kolésnikova in favor of democratization and respect for human rights in Belarus are a source of inspiration for all the world's Democrats. For this reason, our group has proposed that its sacrifice be awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Conscience. Kolésnikova's arrest is a new and intolerable passage in the time tunnel in which the dictatorship has been holding Belarus since 1994. It's time for women in Belarus. Lukashenko identifies feminism with Western values that jeopardize his concept of state. Gender equality has never been on its government's agenda and, according to UN Women's latest report, Belarus tops the list of countries with less participation of women in government positions. She often likes to say that women's vocation is to adorn the world, and that of men, to protect the world and women. No, Mr Lukashenko: the responsibility of a head of government is to promote the progress of all men and women who are born free and equal in rights.  And from the European Union, by our principles, we must listen to the legitimate claim, the courage of thousands of women and men who put their lives at risk. Your fight is your freedom and it's our fight.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, last Wednesday, a month after the so-called presidential elections in Belarus, Svetlana Aleksievitch received anonymous phone calls and was subjected to attempted intrusion into her apartment. Of the seven members of the Coordinating Council, Aleksievitch is the only one who has not been arrested or forced into exile. In response, the ambassadors of our Member States, including Romanian Ambassador Viorel Moanu, who knows very well what repression means, rushed to his home to provide support and protection. A strong symbolic gesture renewed in the following days. This is the Europe that the citizens of Belarus and our neighbourhood need. A Europe that protects those who dare to fight for freedom of expression and democracy. For more than a month, demonstrations of unprecedented magnitude have been taking place throughout Belarus. What a lesson of courage and freedom these citizens of all ages come together under female leadership! They ask Lukashenko to respect the vote cast on 9 August, which was unscrupulously falsified. In response to the demands of the demonstrators, Lukashenko responded as in soviet times: 7,000 people were arrested and more than 450 tortured. Moreover, he imagines enemies (NATO, Europe, the West) and asks for Putin's help, but no lasting solution can be found to this because the only correct path is a peaceful transition from autocratic power to democratic power, the result of a transparent dialogue with the opposition. There is an urgent need for violence and repression to stop. There is also an urgent need for all political prisoners to be released. Europe must do everything in its favour with this solution. Strong and effective sanctions against those responsible for the falsification of elections and repression against the Belarusian people must be put in place as soon as possible. Lukashenko deserves to be at the top of this list. How, in fact, can Belarusian citizens who are fighting for freedom understand that this is not the case? The European Union must also be prepared to ensure the protection of all those fleeing Lukashenko's repression, as well as to actively support that of civil society, political activists and journalists who continue to fight for freedom of expression. If we want the European Union to truly be a credible pillar of support for respect for individual freedoms and democracy, our reactions must be firmer and more effective in the future.

name: Thierry Mariani
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, I know Belarus through many election observation missions that I have been able to carry out in the country over the past 15 years. At each election, the demonstrations denounce the methods of the state and protest against the treatment of the opposition. While it is not new to see Belarusian society moving by the results and the conduct of elections, what constitutes a real change is the scale and determination of these demonstrations. Should we listen to the anger of these protesters? Yes of course. Should we take advantage of their anger to try to manipulate certain minds? I don't think so. The European Union must avoid a new Maidan in Belarus. The sad fate of Ukraine, since this episode influenced from abroad, proves sufficiently that it is through dialogue alone that we will succeed in restoring justice and calm within this country. Yes, we must avoid violence. Yes, those arrested must be released. But let us instead help Belarus to start a genuine national dialogue between the different parties. I think that is the only way to move forward and bring calm to this country.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Developments in Belarus in recent weeks have been dramatic. Hundreds of thousands of peaceful protesters take to the streets every day for freedom and against fake elections. And it is above all the peaceful resistance of women that is incredibly impressive for us. Their courage is unique.  What is extremely shocking, however, is the brutality of the regime with which Lukashenko is taking action against its peaceful citizens. Police violence, martial with Kalashnikovs here on the one hand, roses, dance and music there. Krasser could hardly be the opposite. The images of the emancipation of women and their peaceful resistance expose the dictator. This revolution is female.  The citizens of Belarus currently want only two things: free and fair elections and the release of all political prisoners. The Council of the EU did well not to recognise the election result. Now a unanimous vote for new elections would be important.  The massive police operation, the torture in prisons and the falsification of elections must have consequences for those who order and execute it. That is why we are calling for a tough list of sanctions for all those in the regime apparatus, including Lukashenko, who are involved in the repression of civil society, students in universities and strikers in companies.  Under no circumstances must EU aid or other eu economic aid now lead to further support for the old regime. The money must reach the people of Belarus, not their tormentors. In order to hold the tormentors in Belarus to account, we call for an international commission of inquiry within the mandate of the UN Special Rapporteur against Torture. However, we should also extend the sanctions list to include those who cooperate directly with Lukashenko's regime from Russia, such as the Russian journalists who are taking over the propaganda for Lukashenko on The State Television Channels of Belarus.  Only if all those involved feel that their actions are not without consequences can we be effective. Mr Borrell, take on board with your foreign ministers and see that we do justice to the peaceful demonstrators in Belarus.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The usurper of presidential power in Belarus is willing to sacrifice his country's sovereignty, the security – and in many cases life – of its citizens in exchange for Kremlin guarantees of its duration. We demand an immediate end to the violence in Belarus, the release of all political prisoners, the re-election in accordance with the will of the people. We require Russia to refrain from supporting the usurper.

name: Manu Pineda
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, the European Union is failing in its neighbourhood policy with the Eastern countries. We've seen it in Ukraine, we've seen it in Georgia and now we're seeing it in Belarus.  This failure is the result that, instead of having a foreign policy of our own, we do everything to please the United States in its confrontation with Russia. That is why we have allowed around 20,000 American soldiers to have moved on European territory to the border of a neighbouring country in the European Union in the last year. Instead of acting as an actor that promotes dialogue, peace, negotiation and political channels, the European Union is contributing to a conflict that is a problem for Europe. The United States is again using Europe as a game board to wage another war.  Mr Borrell, the European Union must not take measures to favour a war on European territory, but rather create the necessary conditions to prevent it.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would say to Mr Borrell that I tend to agree with those colleagues who suggest the best the EU can offer to Belarus is the prospect of European values. While Putin offers military support to shore up Lukashenko’s regime, Europe must offer an alternative prospect of a free society, rule of law, democracy and freedom. But how credible is the European Union in doing so if it cannot speak with a single voice on this subject, and if it tolerates Lukashenko—style authoritarianism amongst its ranks, like the Prime Minister of Hungary, Viktor Orbán, who was the last official visitor to Belarus as a symbolic move, and who used this occasion to praise Lukashenko’s regime and to bash the European Union? Ever since, he has been busy constructing a regime which looks very much like that of Lukashenko’s: suppressing press freedom, rigging elections, stifling the opposition and building a corrupt system. All these are attributes of Viktor Orbán’s Hungary today.

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Vice-President of the Commission that we stand together with the Belarusian people. The Belarusian people in their majority are saying to Lukashenko, ‘Get out!’ Putin is standing together with Lukashenko and that is why Lukashenko continues with the violence. From our side, it is not enough only to speak words of solidarity and concern. The EU needs to act and the European Parliament needs to take leadership.  What do we need to do? First, to recognise Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya and the Coordination Council as the legitimate representatives of the people of Belarus and invite them to the European Parliament. Second, to denounce Lukashenko as a criminal usurper if he does not resign when his term in office is over. Third, to start an international investigation into OMON war crimes and to demand that all those who participating in OMON pogroms be included in the EU sanctions list. Fourth, to start to prepare a new Marshall Plan for assistance to democratic Belarus. And fifth, to award the Sakharov Prize to the brave women and men of Belarus. Let’s do it! (The speaker concluded in Belarusian: ‘Zhiv’e Bielarus!’)

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for a long time, Belarus was seen as a black hole on the European map, not only because of its dictatorship but also because of the weak and unambitious EU policy towards that country. Nowadays, Belarus is where we see pride and hope on our continent. The Belarusian people deserve no less than swift, determined and principled action by the European Union. August ninth wasn’t fraud; it was theft. Ever since, we see peaceful protesters being arrested, beaten up, tortured, ‘disappeared’ and even killed. We need broad, targeted sanctions now, including against Lukashenko himself. Finally, I would I like to make a call to all my colleagues here in the European Parliament. We have all seen that freedom’s face in Belarus is female. So let us unite behind giving this year’s Sakharov Prize to the brave women of Belarus.  (The speaker concluded in Belarusian: ‘Zhiv’e Bielarus!’)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the day of 9 August marked the change in the Belarusian people’s perception towards their, and their country’s, future. People no longer tolerate Lukashenko’s dictatorship, fraudulent elections, brutal oppression and economic uncertainty. For the fifth week in a row, tens of thousands of Belarusians in the streets are demanding a halt to violence against peaceful protestors, the organisation of new free and fair elections, and the release of all detained protesters and political prisoners. They are demanding a power transition, as they voted for Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya as their President. The European Union policy line since 2016, based on realpolitik and ignorant to the signals sent by Belarusian civil society, has failed. The EU needs a new approach towards Belarus which includes termination of any cooperation with the Belarusian regime, in particular freezing official membership of the Eastern Partnership initiative, and, instead, supporting the democratic opposition and civil society. The situation in Belarus has become a matter of geopolitics. We witness hybrid intervention from the Russian side, as it seeks to preserve its influence and pursues the continuous ambition of incorporating Belarus into the Russian Federation. We have to stop Russia’s poisoning politics, focused on violating the territorial integrity of its neighbours. Finally, we need solidarity, support and sanctions. I look forward to that policy line of the European Union.

name: Maximilian Krah (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Long before I was elected to this Parliament, I was one of the founding members of the Friendship Society of Germany-Belarus. I can assure you that it is a great people, full of intelligent and pleasant people who, incidentally, are also very conservative – probably the most conservative people we have in Europe. So there is little reason to believe that a feminist revolution is imminent. But this people are fed up with the dictator Lukashenko and his cochos methods. The election is clearly falsified and there needs to be clear pressure to put an end to it.  However, we should always learn from Ukraine's mistakes. There is no reason to link the commitment to popular sovereignty in Belarus with anti-Russian rhetoric, as we have heard here again today. Russia must be put on board and fears of a new Maidan must be allayed if we are realistically to help the Belarusians to become masters of their own country again. Anyone who strikes anti-Russian tones will put Russia alongside Lukashenko and create the conflict that no one here wants.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has had on the work of the rapporteur, Mr Borrell. From the outset, the European Union has supported the aspirations of the people of Belarus for democracy and freedom in this conflict, but has not pursued its own geopolitical objectives.  I think that was the right thing to do. But that doesn't mean others don't. Anyone who has seen the video in which the former dictator, this ridiculous figure Lukashenko, begged Putin to come to his aid, has seen how the weights are being shifted there. Russia has long since begun to shift the weights.  There are two possible futures for Belarus: one Belarusian and one Russian. We have no interest in the second being the case. That is why I agree with saying that we do not want to be anti-Russian. But being against Putin is not anti-Russian, I would like to say that.  However, I believe that we must insist that Lukashenko can only have one function in the future: to hand over Belarus to Putin. That is why we must make it clear that a future, a way out for Belarus, can only exist without Lukashenko.

name: Witold Jan Waszczykowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I believe that Belarus must be the subject of the forthcoming Council and even a more important topic than the Turkish issues. From Belarus, from Minsk to Brussels is closer than from Turkey, and even closer than from Mali. Belarus is the Union's neighbour, it is a European state, it is a member of the Eastern Partnership. Belarus has also been the target of hybrid Russian intervention for many weeks. It is the site of demonstrations lasting more than thirty days in Minsk and many other cities.  Poland, as one of the few countries in the European Union since the beginning of the crisis, has offered a support plan – the Moravian plan. The Visegrad Group was also convinced of this plan. A specific "European Marshall Plan" will be proposed at this nearest Council by Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki.  Will we therefore see an effective intervention by the European Union in the context of the fact that Putin has already offered one and a half billion dollars, and we have only a few million euros? Will we defend this society ... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, I would like to thank Mr Borrell for his work on I agree with everyone. Lukashenko must finally admit that his people want to depose him, instead of relying on repression, intimidation, kidnapping and torture in order to remain in power. A power that he has – always – used for his personal interests, sometimes with Putin, sometimes with the EU. We should not forget that.  We call for the immediate release of all political prisoners, an immediate halt to all repression, police measures and legal action against the gangs in Minsk and other major cities who carry out randomly brutal attacks on citizens.  What is urgently needed is the opening of a transparent and socially broad dialogue to overcome political confrontation, and I agree with all the speakers here in the Chamber. And this dialogue will certainly have to lead to free and fair new elections. In order for this to be possible, however, international moderation is certainly also necessary, at the same time strict restraint and omission of any foreign interference in the country's internal redefinition. This must apply to the Russian Federation, which is contractually linked to Belarus, as well as to the EU and others, that is, within the framework of the OSCE.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Mr President, I grew up singing L’Estaca, the iconic Catalan song of protest that later on became the anthem of revolution in Eastern Europe. Nowadays we hear L’Estaca in the streets of Belarus. People in the streets that want their vote respected, police brutality, hundreds arrested, political opponents sent to jail or exiled – yes, this is happening in Belarus today and, yes, our hearts beat with the people of Belarus in their struggle for civil rights and democracy.  But wait: people in the streets wanting to vote, police violence, political prisoners – have you not seen this elsewhere in Europe? Yes, we have seen this in Catalonia inside the EU. L’Estaca has also returned to the streets of Barcelona and its composer, Lluís Llach, is now one of the leaders in the Catalan Republican Council. This Parliament must stop its hypocrisy if it wants to be credible in upholding civil rights everywhere. First, especially, look after civil rights in the EU.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as the European Parliament we need to make clear firstly that we strongly support the protesting Belarusians and their demands for freedom, dignity, democracy and the right to choose their own destiny. Secondly, that we don’t recognise the results of the presidential elections held in Belarus on 9 August as they were conducted in flagrant violation of all internationally recognised standards, and thirdly that we condemn the ongoing intimidation and disproportionate use of force towards peaceful protesters, participants of strikes and members of the Coordination Council.  High Representative, the restrictive measures targeted against those responsible for the repression in Belarus should be immediately implemented, they are certainly overdue.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the arrest of presidential candidates and peaceful protesters, a violent crackdown on the opposition and civil society – this is a picture of Belarus today that we condemn in the strongest possible terms. Of course we do not recognise the results of the elections, which were neither fair nor free. They did not allow for election observers nor did they respect international standards. New presidential elections must be held. We must insist on targeted sanctions against the perpetrators of acts of violence and repression, including Lukashenko and reassess our relations with Belarus. It must be very clear that we expect Russia to abstain from igniting further violence or repression, also given its latest financial assistance to the regime.  Belarusian citizens, as much as all others, deserve to live in a country where their fundamental freedoms and human rights are respected, where those in government serve the people and where people’s health and safety, and economic and social prosperity are the guideline for all state activity.

name: Karin Karlsbro (Renew).
text: – Mr President, for weeks the people of Belarus have entered the streets with great courage against Lukashenko’s dictatorship and election fraud. But where is the courage of the European Union? Where are the tougher sanctions? it is time to act now. As stated by my colleague Katalin Cseh, slow sanctions are no sanctions. Those responsible for violence and oppression, as well as Lukashenko himself, must be punished, not encouraged. Also, private actors need to be held accountable. European telecom companies taking orders from the regime and cutting mobile internet is of course unacceptable. it is time for the people to decide about their own future. it is time to support Belarus on its own way towards democracy. it is not a question for Putin or anyone else. it is time for us to stand up with the people who want their votes to count. (Applause)

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the belarusian people deserve the right to choose their own leaders. Everything the European Union is doing must now defend the holding of new, democratic and free elections in Belarus. In this situation, a dictator who has lost all support and who is no longer afraid of the people is clinging to any possibility of keeping his power. There is one thing lukashenko has repeatedly clung to: it is hockey. Lukashenko has repeatedly used hockey's ranked competitions and relationships with former NHL stars as a way to bolsh his power and demonstrate that he is appreciated by the outside world. He himself skates there on the field with these guests. In this situation, it is totally unacceptable for the European Union to go to Belarus next spring to support the Lukashenko dictatorship at the World Ice Hockey Championships. We must therefore do all we can to ensure that the International Ice Hockey Federation withdraws the right from Belarus to host these Games, and here we must support Latvia, an EU country whose government has appealed for the same. That is what the Greens require of Parliament and the Union as a whole.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent I see here today the agreement, the agreement that we must support civil society in Belarus. And I'm very happy about that. I think this is a good spurs for the European Commission to act.  Dear! To all these arguments about free elections, about a democratic society, I would like to add one more thing: russian armoured units are stationed in the vicinity of Smolensk today. There is a danger that these units could be moved to Grodno, 600 kilometres to the west, closer to the European Union. We cannot allow this to happen, too, and the support of civil society in Belarus is one of the barriers to these plans that Vladimir Putin may have, which we will be debating here in the context of Mr Natalya in a moment.

name: Andrzej Halicki (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As the first minister said, today we are all in solidarity with belarusians, above factional divisions. The European Parliament has a huge role to play in this dramatic crisis, and I think that it must immediately establish relations with the Coordination Commission representing Belarusian society and with its representative, Swiatłana Cichanouska.  Belarusian society also expects justice. He will not get it at home when torture, beatings and arrests are used. But we have some tools – I have a list of 650 OMON and police officers who were awarded large cash prizes at the end of August. They should be on the list of personal sanctions, they should not be allowed into the European Union and their names should be publicly known. They cannot be anonymous and such tools should be used as part of a support group for Belarusian society.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Lukashenko and Putin are two leaders who are cunning, who are insided, who are adept at playing all the instruments of maintaining power. Now they are coming into dialogue with new proposals, possibly a constitutional amendment, and we as Europeans must not be fooled by this. We must respond wisely with all the instruments that our diplomacy has. Wisely, we need broad international support against the Lukashenko system. We need the involvement of the OSCE, and as a negotiating partner we need the brave and courageous women who are now on the streets of Belarus. These are our possibilities. That is why we must also be clear about the sanctions against Lukashenko and the power elites in Belarus.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew).
text: – Mr President, it is clear that change in Belarus can come from within. It is in the hands of the Belarusian people to not give up and keep on demanding change. However, the EU can still do many things in this situation. Most importantly, it must not be blinded by the role of Russia in this conflict. Lukashenko would not be in power if Russia did not support him. Also, the EU must take a strong stance on Lukashenko and not let itself be manipulated as it has been in past decades. Indeed, when discussing possible sanctions on the individuals responsible for the violence and election manipulations, Lukashenko must be on the list. Lukashenko’s regime, with him in charge, is responsible for the violence and election fraud and should therefore be on the sanctions list. The ultimate goal in Belarus should be new, fair elections. It is also imperative that all those detained and tortured during protests be released and those responsible brought to justice.

name: Beata Mazurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Peaceful protests by belarusian citizens against unfair elections, and at the same time aggressive attempts by the authorities to suppress these protests, are becoming an increasingly serious problem for the whole of Europe. Belarusian society is determined in the struggle for a free and democratic Belarus, belarusian power continues in brutal attempts to suppress the libertarian uprising. Russia's vague stance, which appears to support Lukashenko in its actions, could threaten peace and political stability in the eastern part of the continent.  Previously, the European Union was helpless against Russian aggression in Crimea and eastern Ukraine. We have not learned from these dramatic events. We cannot repeat the same mistakes, we cannot leave our brothers and sisters in Belarus alone. The sovereignty of the Belarusian State is not Polish european interests.  We must demand a repeat of the rigged elections, the release of political prisoners, the punishment of the tormentors and the cessation of the terror that is currently taking place before our eyes. In order to achieve these objectives, a solidarity and firm attitude of all The States of the Community is necessary. We cannot remain passive: let us act and be in solidarity in action. Solidarity with Belarus.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, the European Union, as a guarantor of rule of law and democracy, must be at the side of all peoples. And here there has been a huge electoral fraud, but this electoral fraud is no surprise: the Belarusian regime is one of the most terrible dictatorial regimes we have today. I know him personally, I've been there with the EPP more than once, I've always been persecuted by the KGB, I've seen what the opposition suffer from intermittent and systematic arrests, blackmail and threats on family members.  I know what the Belarusian people are going through, and so I say, we can't give in. We must impose sanctions now, and we must also put pressure on Russia to, together with the European Union, be the guarantor that the Belarusian people can take their fate into their own hands.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – The presence of the Belarusian people on the streets since the August elections is truly impressive, calling for respect for human rights and democracy. Human rights and democracy, it is this agenda that has led thousands of demonstrators to lose their fear and confront the regime that has a dark history of disrespecting freedom. Many have been victims of violence, repression, arbitrary detention, torture and exile. The European Union cannot turn its back on the appeal of trade unionists, students, journalists, men and women who risk their lives. Europe cannot fail to support the Belarusian people.  I have listened carefully to the Commissioner to talk about the support made available and I welcome him, but it is necessary to move towards sanctions on the Lukashenko regime and to demand elections supervised by the OSCE and organised in accordance with the recommendations of the OSCE-ODIHR in previous electoral acts.

name: Charles Goerens (Renew).
text: Mr President, I do not intend to speak on the rubbish side of the so-called last European dictator. A few years ago, maybe it was true, today it is less safe. However, I agree with a cautious and determined approach to the European Union. Indeed, it would be counterproductive to interfere directly in this matter, neither by a bodybuilding on the part of NATO, nor by thoughtful action by the European Union. On the other hand, where we must show determination is in our desire to enforce the texts and conventions or agreements to which all European states have subscribed, including Belarus. Let us also remember that we are alone, terribly alone in this situation. Our main ally practices the language of wood and does nothing. We cannot, of course, do everything, but between everything and nothing, between always and never, there is a small margin, that of an unwavering will to recall the provisions of multilateral institutions, including the OSCE, and to think about how best to bring them to fruition. This is not spectacular, nor is it a guarantee of a quick and favourable outcome. This is not interference, but the renewal of our faith in an international order based on law and not on violence.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let me express my deepest condolences to those who have lost their loved ones in the aftermath of the brutal suppression of peaceful demonstrations. It is crucial that people in Belarus know the full facts about the events in the run—up to, and since, the presidential elections. We need a thorough investigation of the deaths, ongoing disappearances, abductions, violence and electoral fraud. People in Belarus deserve justice. Lukashenko must leave office and new elections must take place.  Belarus and its repressive regime exists in a geopolitical space with its big neighbour that does not provide support to basic fundamental freedoms. It is important that we in the EU provide targeted support to free media and independent civil society in Belarus. It’s also important that Europe stand united in its answer to Lukashenko’s regime. The declaration made by the High Representative, on behalf of the EU, on the presidential elections has been supported by candidate and potential candidate countries in the Western Balkans. Long live Belarus.  (The speaker concluded in Belarusian: ‘Žhiv’e Bielarus!')

name: Nils Ušakovs (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what we are seeing right now is Member State governments trying to discuss a pretty short sanctions list. We are seeing an attempt to find a balance between trade, geopolitics and video footage from Minsk, where we see innocent women being beaten and humiliated by armed men, who are masked without any identification. And while we witness these political calculations, I still believe that we’ve got measures we can introduce almost instantly to help provide support to the Belarusian people. First of all, scholarships for young Belarusians. Lithuania and Poland are doing a lot, but we can still do much more. The visa regime can be made much more liberal for ordinary Belarusians wanting to travel to the European Union. Employment opportunities, especially for highly educated Belarusians. The European Union has capacities and we can do it fast. We must act. (Applause)

name: Bernard Guetta (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to address the Russian President and say: you have a choice, Mr Putin, but do the right thing. Of course, you can snatch a union agreement from a struggling Lukashenko and thus integrate Belarus into Russia, but then you would only lose that country as you lost Ukraine by annexing Crimea. Don't do that, Mr. Chairman. Do not do so, because the Belarusians do not want to break with your country, because NATO does not intend to expand thanks to this crisis, because all the countries of the European Union want a compromise in Minsk and because you would grow up and grow Russia by becoming a peacemaker in Belarus. With this gesture, Mr Putin, you would lay the foundations for cooperation between the European Union and the Russian Federation and change the course of too long a history of distrust and conflict. There is still time, Mr Putin, but this good choice, do it and fast.

name: Rasa Juknevičienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, why Belarus matters to all of the EU, not only to its neighbours is because people in Belarus are fighting for a better Europe as a whole – for a Europe without dictators. The people of Belarus will not give up and they are heroes of Europe because they fight for a European way of life. The people of Belarus can change the European continent because they can change not only Belarus but Russia as well, giving example for Russians. That’s why Putin is afraid of a Belarussian revolution and supports the bloody dictator, Lukashenko.  I call on the EU Member States to fundamentally change their policy from Russia first to Ukraine, Georgia, Moldova, Belarus first. This is the only way to help Russia change and cease being a state that uses chemical weapons against the Kremlin’s critics. (The speaker spoke in Belarusian) ‘Zhiv’e Bielarus!’  President—elect Sviatlana for the Sakharov Prize! EU stay brave.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Mr President, in Minsk and elsewhere in Belarus, peaceful demonstrators, in their tens of thousands, are shouting loudly their rejection of Alexander Lukashenko. They brave intimidation, brutality, imprisonment and even torture. I have a deep admiration for them.  The European Union is right to call for new elections, beyond the refusal not to recognise the results proclaimed. The parallel sometimes raised with Venezuela is quite justified. Here, too, a president refuses a democratic alternation and clings to power by crushing a people in the long run. For these dictators, the fear of an international or even national reputation is no longer taking hold. The lack of reputation, linked to the absolute thirst for power, dictates their decisions against all common sense. This is a dangerous condition, as is the continuation of the current situation in Belarus. Svetlana Tsikanovskaya, the Belarusian Coordinating Council and civil society need our support. Their revolution is a democratic, non-geopolitical revolution. Let Russia agree. Our support is in support of a people hungry for democracy.

name: Leopoldo López Gil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, if any contribution to the development of humanity to improve the well-being of citizens has made Europe, it is the idea and improvement of democracy as a form of government. Because of its fundamental principle—the vote—Belarusians have been peacefully demonstrating for five consecutive weeks in the face of fraud by dictator Lukashenko.  Last Sunday, 250 arrests were reported, with a lot of violence against the participants of these marches. Today, surely, with the reports we have, there will also be tortured. The European Union cannot fall into the trap of legitimizing electoral fraud. With harsh sanctions, it must force dialogue with the legitimate representatives of the opposition to hold verifiable elections and respect for sovereign will.  As the father of a disabled leader, imprisoned, persecuted by satrapas twinned by the use in his behaviour of torture and abuse against his opponents, I want to exalt the importance of sanctions on human rights violators and usurpers of legitimate power. I call for an unequivocal, strong resolution condemning the Lukashenko regime.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr High Representative, thank you very much for being here with us today. It is not least if we have to remember all the sad events that occurred on 4 August and which have been repeated, by the way, with a new fire in the port of Lebanon.  In the bombing of 4 August, the general secretary of Kataeb, a member party of Lebanon's associated European People's Party, Was lost his life. A man who fought for democracy and freedoms in Lebanon all his life.  It is not new, since the European People's Party is the only European party that has always strongly committed to having a presence, not only vocal as we are now all doing for the cause of Lebanon, but also pragmatic, with the inclusion of these parties as our partners. These parties of ours have always systematically denounced the corruption of the system. For this reason, many of them have not wanted to participate, because they have always denounced that behind corruption in the case of Lebanon is undoubtedly the hand, the foreign interference of Syria and Iran through Hezbollah. I have no doubt the efforts being made by European countries — and there is no need to be Emmanuel Macron — to stand in solidarity clearly with Lebanon, which is such a close country, so dear to us Europeans, that we all agree — and I am convinced that political forces too — to support the efforts of the Commission and the Council also on the money currently being given to the cause and help the Lebanese people. But I wanted to ask you, Mr Representative, Mr Borrell, on the question of Hezbollah. What are we going to do? Many countries, of course, have put it on the list of terrorist organizations. Does the European Union have any opinions on this?

name: Isabel Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, the explosion in the port of Beirut has found Lebanon in a bit of a way, in the face of the pandemic and plunged into a profound economic, political and social crisis that imposes an extensive reform process and an intense fight against corruption, accompanied by a full assumption of responsibility for all political actors. The resilient Lebanese people did not deserve such an ordeal.  Now it is necessary, above all, to ensure that aid reaches quickly to those who have become homeless, to those in need of health care and food and that it is delivered to those who need it, without any kind of spurious exploitation.  I welcome the sending of aid through several European countries, such as Portugal and Germany, and the visit a few days ago by Commissioner Lenarčič. Modernisation and reforms are fundamental to the recovery and reconstruction of the country, but require dialogue between all political and social forces, and the European Union has a crucial role to play, avoiding the conquest of space by geopolitical interests with harmful consequences for the Lebanese people and the region.  (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Nathalie Loiseau
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, we are celebrating the 100th anniversary of the creation of the State of Greater Lebanon. Yet Lebanon in 2020 is not at the party. It is going through a series of crises that cannot leave us indifferent. I would like to welcome here the commitment of the French President, Emmanuel Macron, on behalf of France but also of Europe as a whole, which proves to the Lebanese people that they are not alone. More than anyone else, our Parliament must hear the aspirations of this angry Lebanese people, who know what they want and above all what they no longer want. The Lebanese people are unsy and no longer unsyuming with the corruption that plagues the country. There needs to be an international and independent investigation into the Beirut port explosion and impunity must end. Not only must European aid go to the people it supports, but we must also insist that Lebanon's anti-corruption body finally become operational. On the other hand, one day we will have to look at the ill-gotten Lebanese assets that lie dormant in European banks. We will not be able to continue to look elsewhere. The Lebanese people can no longer be represented by a political class that has no other struggle than that of its own survival and its own privileges. Its civil society is dynamic and courageous and must be able to be heard. Our duty is to help him. We should thereby support technically and financially the establishment of a national consultation platform. Lebanon is much more than a small country to the east of the Mediterranean. Lebanon has always been a promise: that of reconciliation between the denominations and communities of the Middle East, that of a free, educated and prosperous society. The survival of this promise and its victory over the forces that want to stifle it depend very much on us.

name: Elena Lizzi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, the terrible explosion that devastated Beirut on 4 August is rapidly leading Lebanon into a bloody anarchist revolution, of those they destroy without building anything. It is certainly Europe's job to propose solutions to help the cedar country and not to leave political space for states such as Turkey or Iran, in a strategic country on the Middle East chessboard. But the European Union's intervention must take place under certain conditions: Lebanon, in fact, is facing corruption and a clientele system that needs reforms demanded by civil society itself.  The European Union must check how and from whom both first aid funds and reconstruction funds in Beirut will be used. The proposal by those who would like to bypass money through NGOs is also somewhat perplexing, in the light of the European Court of Auditors' criticism of transparency in reporting ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Salima Yenbou
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Borrell, in view of the notorious problems of corruption and abuse of power by Lebanese political leaders, what concrete steps is the European Union taking to ensure that humanitarian aid is actually provided to those who need it most in Lebanon, including vulnerable groups, such as refugees, migrant workers, women, children, the elderly and the disabled? Many NGOs, not just Lebanese for that matter, complain that international aid often does not reach the people who really need it, but disappears into the pockets of corrupt elites. Some NGOs suggest that we combine concrete safeguards to combat corruption and support reform demands. What do you think of that? Indeed, until reforms take place, the risk of disasters, such as the fire that destroyed Red Cross aid equipment, will not be behind us. We must help the Lebanese to carve out this raw jewel of the East by getting rid of corruption and to build its democracy and freedom. I stress that most Lebanese seem satisfied and grateful for the strong involvement of the French president. I then ask you: where is Europe in all this? What role does or does it not play in Lebanon? How can Europe support reforms? The President of the European Council, Charles Michel, visited Beirut on 8 August and the European Commissioner for Crisis Management, Janez Lenar-i, on 12 September. Mr. Borrell, when are you going to go to Lebanon? When did the President of the European Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, plan to go to Lebanon, which Fairuz sang [phrase in Arabic], the "dignified Lebanon and its beating people" with which we must be?

name: Beata Kempa
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Lebanon cries and cries for help. The situation before the explosion was already very dramatic. Not only have strategic grain reserves been destroyed, but above all a stockpile of medical supplies brought into the country in connection with the coronavirus pandemic. If we add to this the famine, the dire situation of Syrian and Palestinian refugees, the people who are losing their jobs, and the pandemic, then the situation with regard to this situation of the most vulnerable Lebanese is dramatic. A third of Beirut's residents without a roof over their heads are children. Let's pay attention to this – these are young children. Today, as the High Representative has told us, these funds must indeed be channeled directly to the beneficiaries and my country has directed these measures. Two organizations "Redemptoris Missio" and "Helping the Church in Need" with the support of the Polish military have recently brought tons of food, as well as disinfectants. But this aid, which should go to the poorest, needs much more, and that is the task of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, before the crisis in Lebanon we witnessed many demonstrations in Lebanon by young people, young people fighting corruption, who were fighting the economic crisis that has affected them, against poverty, against unemployment. But in reality the chemical crisis has also been accompanied by a huge explosion and these young people are now in need of our support. Not only the young Lebanese, but also so many refugees who were able to settle there following the enormous generosity of the Lebanese people.  In this sense, I believe that the European Union cannot escape this call, an appeal to support the Lebanese people, either by the instruments it already has, in the neighbourhood, the Trust Fund, or by UNRWA, but to respond to the population and refugees, more than one million Syrian refugees, about half a million Palestinian refugees.  This is also the time to avoid temptation, not to have political exploitation, to have no interference, not to have geopolitical games. European solidarity must be the answer to Lebanese generosity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing my solidarity and closeness to our Lebanese friends: you are not and will not be alone in the challenge of reconstruction, not only infrastructural, but also, and above all, social and economic.  I wish the new Prime Minister, Mustapha Adib, good luck in the formation of the new government, and I would like to take this opportunity to warn all the leaders involved in the negotiations: in the face of extraordinary circumstances, we need a sense of responsibility and we need extraordinary courage; put aside political differences and personal interests: we need a determined government that will have to face a humanitarian emergency and fight, without quarter, corruption and clientelism.  Reforms are necessary and urgent, but they must be shared and supported from the bottom up, involving in particular those young people who have been clasping for months in the squares for a new, modern, transparent and above all free Lebanon. Without peace and social justice in Lebanon, there will never be peace and social justice throughout the Middle East.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Mr President, since 4 August, Lebanon has been experiencing a succession of fires after this explosion. We have no right to resign ourselves to the date marking the agony of this beloved country of Europe and France. Europe must do everything, first of all to ensure the neutrality of Lebanon, a country martyr of all the conflicts that cross the region. This means finally pushing Hezbollah to accept the disarmament of militias under UN conventions, which will allow the country to regain its sovereignty by getting rid of foreign interference. Europe must finally punish the members of this corrupt political class who have sold off their country's sovereignty. We must move from words to action today and the fight against corruption and the tracing of European aid must finally become an effective reality. Finally, Europe must demand this international investigation which will enable us to know the real culprits of this devastating explosion and the crimes it has caused. It is peace today in Lebanon or chaos in the Middle East. Let us remember that Europe was born in this country, tells us mythology.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, the explosion in the port of Beirut, which caused hundreds of deaths, thousands of injuries, more than 300,000 homeless people, and the complete destruction of the city's neighbourhoods is in addition to the stalemate that has led millions of Lebanese, already in October 2019, to show their anger at an inefficient and corrupt political system. The Lebanese people are calling for change: a religiously neutral country, effective and progressive institutions... Above all, he wants to turn the page on corruption. As we know, Lebanon, since its independence, is the ground where the influence of regional powers and their allies is exerted. However, our duty as Europeans is to stand with the Lebanese. We are facing a humanitarian emergency and we must ensure that Europe's resources go directly to the people. We see the urgency of political and economic reconstruction: helping civil society to adopt the reforms now demanded by the IMF will give the country the opportunity to return to the economic and political scene and to be able to release 11 billion euros in aid. This civil society knows what it wants, we have to work with it.

name: Jan-Christoph Oetjen (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The explosion in the port of Beirut on 4 August killed more than 200 people, injured 6 500 and lost 300 000 people. The images were terrifying. I would like to take this opportunity to express my solidarity with the Lebanese people. We must now do everything we can to ensure that aid arrives where it is urgently needed: the people.  But this help is just a patch on an open wound. Decades of mismanagement, corruption, political chaos, and the aftermath of the Corona pandemic have led to an unprecedented economic infarction. The country has been insolvent since March. The population is impoverished and many well-educated people are leaving the country. In addition, the six million Lebanese now host 1.5 million Syrian refugees.  Without outside help, there will soon be no money left to import food or essential medicines. We Europeans offer our full support. But this also requires a fundamental rethink of Lebanon's ruling class. I therefore welcome President Macron's initiative to call for fundamental reforms. Europe must join these demands, because people have lost faith in politics. There must be no "continuing like this".

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Mr President, we can only rejoice to see Lebanon on the agenda of our parliamentary debates today, as the images of 4 August have affected the world. With its friendship and historical ties, France was the first to support the Lebanese people in this humanitarian and economic tragedy. It is now in everyone's interest to ensure that Lebanon, the crossroads of all political and religious tensions, does not fall into a crisis that would sow the seeds of a new civil war. The Christian quarter of Beirut, the beating heart of the city, is nothing more than a pile of ruins: this is a symbol that we must consider. While Christian minorities throughout the Middle East are more threatened than ever, the peace and stability of a country where they enjoy relative tolerance is more vital than ever. We know that the European Union has the greatest embarrassment in invoking its roots, but France here has a mission imposed by its history and with which it cannot break without betraying itself: to protect the Christians of the East. The economic and logistical support we have to offer Lebanon is not discussed. It must live up to history and is, I have no doubt, a subject on which we will probably all finally agree.

name: Jakop G. Dalunde (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Lebanon is a resilient country that has endured many challenges; but after the tragic explosion in Beirut’s harbour, Lebanon is on the brink of disaster. The Lebanese people are sick and tired of having to be resilient, and I understand them. In this dire situation, the first priority must be to form an impartial government that is able to tackle the immediate crisis. I call upon Europe to support, in any way possible, the formation of such a government.  Decades of corruption must come to an end. The Lebanese people deserve leaders who solve problems, not cause them. They deserve leaders who inspire hope, not despair. These leaders exist. I have met them. They are young, capable and visionary. They fight for social justice, human rights and sustainability. Many of them are women who struggle in the face of patriarchal elites. We have to support them. Europe needs to support them.

name: Benoît Lutgen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, the Lebanese people are friendly people, they are our brothers. In the current situation, we must support them, of course, through our declarations, but even more so in the various much-needed reforms: political reform, on the one hand, but also disarmament, especially of militias, in accordance with United Nations Security Council Resolution 1599, or, of course, the provision of the budgetary support necessary to lift the country. The Lebanese are certainly bruised, but they are standing. I ask that we be able to send a delegation of the European Parliament quickly - I have already written in this regard, in order to be accompanied by the High Representative - to create, to forge even more and further these important links between Europe and the Lebanese people and to accompany these necessary reforms in support of the Lebanese people.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, this summer in Lebanon it rained on wet conditions. The catastrophic consequences of the explosion in Beirut Harbour have ended up aggravating what was already a deep economic and political crisis in the country, plunged for months into protests and social discontent. A country that has suffered, as we well know, from the turbulence in the region and which has made a huge effort in recent years to host refugees.  That is why the European Parliament is now calling for a common position between the European institutions and the Member States for reconstruction, the necessary reconstruction of Lebanon. A coordinated position. All of them. And that is why it will also be necessary for those responsible for the explosion to be investigated in Lebanon, to take on the consequences, to get a government up and running at once, and there will be reforms. Reforms to end an inoperative and sectarian governance method, which has so often opened the door to corruption.  Lebanon needs us and, above all, the Lebanese people are exhausted.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – Mr President, six weeks ago a massive explosion rocked the port area of Lebanon’s capital Beirut. It killed over 200 people, injured 7 000 and destroyed one third of the city. The blast hit both Lebanese as well as refugee and migrant communities from Syria who make up 30% of Lebanon’s population. I’m proud to see the support provided by the European Union to Lebanon. Firstly, the swift activation of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. Secondly, immediate assistance from the EU Copernicus satellite service and, thirdly, donations of money, medical supplies, food and equipment. We must continue helping the Lebanese population at this time of need. We must also strongly encourage the Lebanese authorities to undertake critical structural reforms. Lebanon is a fragile state. Let’s help support its people to maintain it and my message to the Lebanese people is: you will rise like a phoenix from the ashes, I have no doubt.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: " Mr President, first of all, I would like to transfer sympathy and solidarity to the Lebanese people following the devastation caused by the explosion of 4 August in the port of Beirut with the consequences we all know, particularly given that Lebanon , in addition to many other dimensions mentioned – is the country that currently hosts the largest number of per capita refugees in the world , with about one million Syrian citizens.  I support, of course, the words of the High Representative and the actions of the Commission and the European Union as a whole to assist in reconstruction. But, as other members have said, I think we need to pay close attention to the reform of the political system, with a force like Hezbollah, which works in the service of Iran and Syria and, in general, a system of confessional parties that are not acceptable in a democracy. I believe that this is the real challenge of the Lebanese political system: political parties that do not respond to confessional keys.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I just saw Alexei Navalny's first tweet with a photo from the hospital. He has now breathed the first night without help and on his own. I think we all wish him a good recovery here.  He was poisoned with Novichok. This has been established by a German laboratory, and laboratories in France and Sweden have confirmed this through the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. This is only the latest case in the long series of political assassinations at home and abroad. There is little doubt as to who is responsible for this – if not criminally, then at least politically – the master of the Kremlin.  I do not think we should look at this attack in isolation when we think together about how we respond. There is only one Russian government that is not in favour of freedom, democracy, cooperation and transparency in many ways at home, but also outside Russia. A holistic approach must take this act as an opportunity to effectively sanction behaviour in Belarus, Donbass, Crimea, Georgia, Moldova and Syria.  To all those who are concerned, I call on: stop looking at this putinist Russia and saying it beautifully! Unfortunately, it is a systemic adversary that is doing everything it can to weaken the EU, to destabilise the democratic states as a whole, because our way of organising society is more attractive and fascinating in its sphere of influence than what its structures have to offer behind the state facade. So, let us agree on the approach to this country and make the necessary (the President withdraws the speaker's speech.)

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, ‘Alexei Navalny’ is a name President Putin refuses to say out loud, hoping this will make him irrelevant. But Navalny’s popular support, his intimidation and arrest by the authorities, and now his poisoning actually show the opposite. This is a man with impact, exposing the massive corruption by the Kremlin and its allies. Following this assassination attempt, Navalny is now added to a long list of Russian citizens who have been a thorn in the side of the authorities. Navalny was poisoned with a chemical nerve agent to which only the Russian military and intelligence agencies have access, so there is no need for a guessing game as to who bears responsibility. To demand a real investigation by the Kremlin would – we can say from experience – be wishful thinking. It won’t happen, just as it never happened with the other poisonings or the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight 17 (MH17). The Kremlin’s denial, however, is not a reason to fail to hold Moscow accountable for a very serious violation of international law. If ever we were serious about the EU’s strategic autonomy, this is the moment to put that theoretical academic concept into practice, and to do so by cancelling Nord Stream 2. I wish Mr Navalny a speedy recovery. (Applause)

name: Bernard Guetta
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, no, we do not know who sponsored this crime, but we know that the opposition is a deadly disease under Mr Putin. So let's leave the question of who, because the only question that arises is the question of why. For the Russian regime, nothing is right anymore. In the east, the Khabarovsk protests do not stop, while in the west, every Sunday, Belarus takes to the streets to demand its freedom. As oil prices plummet and coffers empty, living standards plummet in Russia and even Syria. Mr. Putin has been left alone since the Assad clan split up and the Iranian theocracy loses its footing. So this regime is afraid because Victor Hugo said: "nothing is more imminent than the impossible". Communist Poland had not seen Solidarity coming, Mr Lukashenko had not felt the anger rising around him and anything can happen in this powder shop that becomes Russia. So, yes, Mr Putin, you are right to be afraid and, before it is too late, before unrest reaches your country and makes you worse than this poisoning, facilitate a compromise in Belarus, withdraw from Ukraine, give freedom to the Russian people, let them breathe rather than make them cry one after another the best and bravest of their children. Mr. Navalny poisoned and all your opponents disappeared.

name: Thierry Mariani
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Mr High Representative, for once I have found your position perfectly balanced. Yes, of course, we all wish Mr Navalny to be reinstated. Yes, we want an independent investigation first and foremost and wait until we know who is the real culprit. When I listen, in this Chamber, some people demonize Russia all day long and already know the results of the investigation before it has even begun. Some, then, are war criminals who did not even wait a day to demand new sanctions against Russia. Those nostalgic for the Cold War want to use all the dramas to start an East-West confrontation. But soothsayers and war-makers have forgotten one thing: Russia is a signatory to the Chemical Weapons Convention. Novitchok has been part of the OPCW protocol since last year. The international investigation is therefore provided for in international law, except that the law stipulates that the first investigation is first conducted by Russia, which, until proven otherwise, is a sovereign state. Russia is neither below nor above international law. Neither are the war-makers and the soothsayers of the European Parliament. Let's wait for the results of a real investigation.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, our sympathy is with Alexei Navalny and his family. The attempt on his life is something that we have known before, for many years. Opposition leaders and independent journalists in Russia are not safe – from Politkovskaya to Nemtsov, from Kara—Murza to Verzilov. Those are just the names that we know.
