The list of victims pains us, because we have grown with pain together with the Russian people: with the parents and brother of Navalny, with the daughter of Nemtsov, with the daughter of Anastasia Shevchenko, who has been locked up for months without any reason. The only reason is that they dared to dream. They dared to dream about freedom – something which is absolutely natural to us – and yet they are branded as foreign agents, they are called undesirable organisations, and they are dehumanised on the propaganda TV. Anyone who claims that Europe doesn’t care about Russia, listen to these words. We want a strategic partnership with Russia, but we want this strategy to be a strategy towards democracy and towards civil rights, a strategy for people and not for corrupt Russian elites, and not for a gas project to undermine our neighbours, not for a nuclear plant in Hungary, and not a strategy on how to harbour the assets of corrupt individuals in the European Union.  Until this strategy exists, we need truth. We need truth about the poisoning. For that, we wrote to Mr Borrell and the German Presidency and called for an international investigation. We know the truth about the assets of corrupt individuals in Europe. For this we can use the list drawn up by Navalny’s organisation itself in order to go for them.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Politkovskaya, Magnitsky, Litvinenko, Nemtsov, Skripal, opponents of the Kremlin, victims of Kremlin and now Alexei Navalny poisoned with the military-grade nerve agent Novichok. It is time to stop Putin’s impunity. It is time to impose broader sectoral sanctions. Let us start with stopping Nord Stream 2. (Applause)

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we condemn what has happened and convey our best wishes for recovery and solidarity to Mr Navalny. Any use of chemicals is inhumane, illegal and intolerable; a complicated and troubling issue that requires independent positioning. But we must ask ourselves what we want to achieve with this Parliament's resolution. Every time we talk about Russia or the countries of the East, we only strain the relations of the European Union, in a somewhat hypocritical way because all parties know that we have close trade and energy relations; the Nord Stream project is an example of this. And I ask: what benefits can the possible use of sanctions have on the peoples of the European Union and on the Russian people?  We're still tied to alliances from the last century. Ukraine is an example of this. We renounce the construction of an independent neighbourhood and foreign policy and contribute to an escalation of tensions which, by the way, does not make the European Union a safer place.  We must build just trade relations, denounce human rights violations and not allow their constant instrumentalization. Promoting peace and human rights is beginning with changing these neighbourhood policies, and today I cannot fail to mention, in this Parliament, that we must also fulfil human rights within the territory and that what we are... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there is no need to explain what a brutal crime was executed against Alexei Navalny, the leader of the political opposition in Russia. Novichok, regular attempts to kill opposition leaders, and permanent support to all dictators, from Maduro to Lukashenko – these are the main features of Kremlin policies.  That is why today we need to speak not only about the Navalny case. We need to speak about our policy towards Russia – or, more precisely, towards Putin. I have a dream that Russia can be different. The democratic revolution in Belarus makes this dream much more realistic. Alexei Navalny is fighting for this dream to become a reality, and the EU needs to stand together with the people of Russia, who want to live in a democracy. Let’s stop our attempts to build an unconditional friendship with Putin, who is stealing that dream, not only from the Russian people. The poisoning of Navalny is a wake-up call to all of us! We need to make an in-depth review of our strategy towards Russia: democracy in Russia should be our priority, not business as usual of the Nord Stream 2 type.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we deeply regret the assassination attempt against Alexei Navalny and express our utmost concern about this repeated use of chemical and nerve agents against Russian citizens.  Russian authorities should finally put an end to the harassment, intimidation, violence and repression against their political opponents by ending the prevailing impunity. Journalists, human rights defenders and opposition politicians have to be able to conduct their legitimate activities without fear for their lives.  Our relations with Russia are at a low point; characterised by mistrust caused by Russia’s actions in violation of international law in Ukraine, intervention in Syria, the spread of disinformation and fake news. Of particular concern is the high-level support by Russia to extreme anti-European forces in the European Union. Nevertheless, some pragmatic engagement with Russia should continue in areas where it is still possible and necessary for the interest of global governance.  This is why the five guiding principles for the EU policy towards Russia should serve as a base for a much-needed new comprehensive strategy towards Russia. A strategy that should primarily be based on the need for respect for international law and human rights standards, while strengthening peace and security.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I say to the High Representative and the House: it’s incredible I think that in 2020 people are poisoned to silence them for their political ideas, and it’s not the first time this has happened. I would like to wish Mr Navalny a quick recovery. Our group condemns firmly the poisoning of Mr Navalny. We ask Russia to investigate in a transparent and impartial manner the assassination attempt on Alexei Navalny, and we ask Russia to bring to justice those responsible for it on whatever level they might be. For me, it’s very clear with everything that happens with Russia, and colleagues have said it already: we need, Mr Borrell, a new EU-Russia strategy, one of sticks and carrots and we need to adopt an ambitious EU human rights sanctions regime. Let’s make work of it.  (Applause)

name: Gunnar Beck (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has According to the Federal Government, Alexei Navalny was undoubtedly administered Novichok nerve agent.  Apparently independent but well-picked laboratories in Sweden and France would have confirmed this Bundeswehr finding. Navalny's Russian doctors, however, found no evidence of poisoning. The vote of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons is still pending. It is common ground that since the 1990s, at least 20 states and organised criminals have acquired possession of the poison.  So what do we know? Poisoning seems entirely possible, but it has not been proven beyond doubt. Was poisoned, then apparently in Siberia. The perpetrator remains unclear, however, only some people have motives. We know little more than almost nothing, and we debate courageously, but probably prematurely and almost fact-free.

name: Pär Holmgren (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Yesterday it was 37.9 degrees in France. It's a new September record for that country. In hundreds of places here in western Europe, new heat records were broken, and there are likely to be even more today. This extremely late high summer heat is another example and a reminder of global warming. In the midst of this, literally, burning climate crisis, Russia wants to build europe, not least Germany, into a long-term dependence on fossil energy through the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline. If Nord Stream 2 is stopped, the possibility will increase that we will, after all, succeed with the climate targets that we voted on last week in, among other things, the Committee on the Environment. Furthermore, the German Government will have an opportunity to strongly mark against Russia and against Putin, given how these recurring ly treat political opponents and dissidents in a totally unacceptable way.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First, sympathy for Mr. Nawal and his family, and wishes for his recovery. Secondly, the need for a swift and credible investigation. Thirdly, Russia is weakening economically and, contrary to appearances, is losing influence in its traditional regions of influence, such as Central Asia, the South Caucasus and Central and Eastern Europe.  This, I believe, is a signal to Moscow that it should seek dialogue with the European Union, for dialogue with the West. Situations such as those with Mr. Navalev, the attempted murder, previously casus Litvinenko, Nemtsov, Skripala – this spoils the image of Russia, it encourages the imposition of sanctions on Russia, and this is the worst way for Russia to be a partner of Europe.

name: Peter van Dalen (PPE).
text: – President, Sergey Yushchenko, Anna Politkovskaya, Boris Nemtsov and now Alexei Navalny. Some names on the long list of Russians who have been murdered or poisoned by the dictator in Moscow. And, as a Dutchman, I am of course thinking more of another crime by the Russians: a Book missile that brought down flight MH17. We must now take a strong stand against Russia and against this regime. And you can. Let's correct the biggest Western European geostrategic blunder ever now! Stop Nord Stream 2. What kind of thing has ever figured out that we need to become more dependent on Putin's gas supply? In short, we must now completely isolate this regime.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i join my voice with my colleague van Dalen to remind Mr Sergei Iuchtchenko, Alexander Litvitiniov, Anna Politkowskaja, Natalia Estemirova, Sergei Magnitski, Boris Nemtsov, too long a list of Mr Putin's political opponents, journalists, human rights activists murdered and whose deaths occurred in mysterious circumstances.  Let us be clear, there is a pattern of physical elimination of uncomfortable figures to Mr Putin's regime that cannot go unpunished. In the case of the poisoning of Alexei Navalny it is necessary to quickly deliver evidence of the use of the neurological agent of the novichok family gathered by the German authorities and confirmed by French and Swedish laboratories and that the Russian Federation cooperates in an independent and impartial investigation and that all those responsible .... (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the names of many of the victims of these poisonings have been said here; they were partly traitors who had fled—deserters, as they would be described in the Kremlin—now they are opponents.  Russia enters a very, very difficult economic situation: Putin has been in his twenties and Putin has done very few things besides strengthening himself in power. Now he enters a much more unstable situation for him and it is clear that what he wants is to sow terror and create fear with this case. That is why I believe that the signals so that this list does not add up and does not expand infinitely have to be very, very clear, and the signals can no longer be any sanctions, such as those that are being there— which are partly ignored and camouflaged; they have to be clear signals, such as the immediate suspension of Nord Stream 2, which would be a very clear sign that the European Union and, above all, Germany do not tolerate these things happening and that these crimes are done business as usual.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first I would like to wish Alexei Navalny a speedy and full recovery. For years now, we have seen a consistent trend in Russia: elimination of opposition and critics of the regime with the most brutal tactics. We cannot accept that in Europe in the 21st century we witness the use of chemical weapons against political opponents. We must act united in our response, and I’m sorry to say that the representatives of the German EU Council Presidency have left the room before this debate. We cannot be engaged in any other conversation with Russia besides the one in which together in the European Union we hold Russia responsible, and demand clear answers and explanations from Moscow. And we must act in line with our words. Indeed, in this situation, we cannot conduct business deals or carry out strategic infrastructure projects with Moscow.  Europe’s economic relations with Russia must depend on acceptable political relations, not the other way around.  (Applause)

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Alexei Navalny has been poisoned for denouncing the grievances in Russia. Navalny should be silenced, and it should poison criticism and opposition. Time and again, opponents are being evicted from the way in Russia, but the opposition's voice could not be completely silenced in the regional elections– and that is a good thing. Democracy is a weak plant in Russia and belongs strengthened. In Novosibirsk, "United Russia" has suffered losses. But – and I think this is very important to emphasise – even if there is an attempt to poison and eliminate opponents time and again, the desire for democracy, the struggle for democracy, cannot be poisoned.

name: Rasa Juknevičienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will start by saying that Germany has played a decisive role by taking Navalny to a safe environment, by saving Navalny’s life and by establishing that this was indeed a military chemical weapon attack. But we need another important step: to withdraw from the Nord Stream 2 project. Why? Because with the money for gas, the Kremlin regime is able to develop such chemical weapons as Novichok and to finance such operations as the poisoning of Alexei Navalny.  The EU countries cannot be complicit. Putin is guilty of this and a series of other murders. The Russian authorities cannot be trusted with an investigation. The EU must lead the initiative for an international investigation into the poisoning of Navalny and into the breach of Russia’s international commitments by using chemical weapons.

name: Riho Terras (PPE).
text: – Mr Vice-President, i would like to express my thanks for your support. Today we are discussing the case of alexei Navalny's poisoning. Various laboratories have already confirmed that the Russian positsion was poisoned with a novitshock, whose production capacity is only in the russian federation's national laboratories, and its use could only be approved by senior management, that is to say, Vladimir Putin. We wish Alexei Navalny a speedy recovery, of course, and we hope that his health will recover from this cowardly attack. Removing its own citizens is just one of the dirty methods of this KGB sub-colonel's arsenal. The Putin regime poses a threat to the whole of Europe. My question is, how does the European Union plan to protect its citizens from russia's aggressive actions in a situation where the costs of the european Union's next long-term budget in the area of defence have been severely cut?

name: Eugen Tomac (PPE).
text: – Mr. Vice-President, who is Navalny's poisoning? This is no longer an isolated case, but we are witnessing, behold, a Stalinist way of action by which the opponents of the Putin regime are eliminated. Moreover, this policy of aggression does not stop at the border. Moscow practices and understands only the language of power externally, defying any principle of international law. What we can do: act uniformly and harder than ever to stop this primitive way in which democracy is being liquidated by the Kremlin. Russia must be sanctioned. Russia is obliged to quickly accept an international investigation into Navalny. Sanctions must target the institutions and companies that endorse the Putin regime. This regime can only be stopped if we act now firmly and without any concession, regardless of the consequences. Here we are talking about life and values that cannot be negotiated with anyone. Vice-President Borrell, you have a responsibility to act firmly and categorically to promote European values in our neighbourhood. Foreign policy starts in the neighbourhood.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you and I thank the Members for all their contributions to the debate. I don’t have a lot of time to summarise. We are using all the tools that we have at our disposal to contribute to the end of the violent repression that has been developing in Belarus after the elections, which we don’t consider to legitimise Lukashenko. We support a peaceful and democratic solution to the crisis through political engagement, restrictive measures, increased support to civil society and an independent media. This is what we can do and that’s what we are doing. Don’t ask for things that are out of the competences of the European institutions. Sometimes you ask for a decision that belongs to the Member States for which, I’m sorry, but I cannot feel responsible.  I try to work within the framework of the European institutions’ treaties and the capacities we have. And, believe me, it’s not always easy. We are still discussing about the sanctions in Belarus, and my main purpose is to try to approve them with an agreement on the technical working groups of the Council, in order to have it approved before European Union Council. But we will continue engaging on the situation in Belarus, with all the tools at our disposal. On Lebanon, we will require Lebanon to implement reforms. Helping to ensure the stability of the country and the stability of the region. We will allocate the resources we have, but you know that we are at the end of the financial perspective, and as long as we don’t have new resources, we cannot do more than we are doing.  Some of you ask about changing the position on Hezbollah. For the time being, the EU position on Hezbollah remains unchanged. The military wing of Hezbollah is on the sanctions regime. The presence of Hezbollah in the government is not new, and we are convinced that engaging in a constructive dialogue with all political parties gives the possibility of strengthening its institutions, including the Lebanese Armed Forces and the state security agencies, and this is key for the stability of Lebanon and the Middle East. But in order to change the position on Hezbollah, it would require, once again, unanimity from all Member States, and this is not the case. Finally, on the situation in Russia, and in particular about Mr Navalny, we continue calling on Russia to investigate this crime through a fully transparent procedure under the auspices of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. For sure, we can expect that the poisoning of Mr Navalny will have an impact on European Union-Russia relations. We are going to discuss that at the next Foreign Affairs Council.  Some of you talk about the possibility of this affecting Nord Stream 2, well this is the once again something that is out of the possibilities of the European institutions. What I can tell you is that the Commission has never shown a lot of enthusiasm for this gas pipeline. The Commission does not consider it a relevant infrastructure priority, but it is something that is up to the Member States that have been pushing for this infrastructure to be built. This is apart from the scepticism from the Commission, which has never shown a strong support for it.  And finally, about the possibility of a sanction in Russia with a kind of Magnitsky-style regime. Since I took office, I immediately launched a global human rights sanctions regime, which has been discussed once again in the last Foreign Affairs Council. Discussion continues in the Council, legal acts are currently being drafted. I hope that what has happened with Mr Navalny will represent encouragement for the Member States to stop discussing and start acting, and approving this human rights sanctions regime. In the same way that the Americans speak of Magnitsky legislation, we could call it our Navalny sanctions regime. This would be a good way of taking stock of what is happening and to keep on the record for the future the fact that Mr Navalny’s name is associated with a sanctions regime for people who have violated human rights.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The joint debate is closed.  The votes on the amendments to the motions for resolutions on the situation in Belarus and on the motions for resolutions on the situation in Russia and the poison attack on Alexei Navalny will take place on Wednesday, 16 September 2020, and the final votes will take place on Thursday, 17 September 2020.

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The credibility of the Russian Federation in international relations in recent years has been undermined primarily by its actions in Georgia and Ukraine, as a result of which the Russian Federation, in violation of all its rules, has violated the sovereignty and territorial integrity of these countries.  Other actions taken in violation of all international rules and standards also need to be explained. This is confirmed m.in suspicions directed at the Kremlin of poisoning Sergei Skripal in the UK, murdering a Chechen fugitive in Berlin's Tiergarten park or carrying out a hacking attack on the Bundestag. There is a real suspicion that the Russian Federation is behind the attack on Alexei Navatal. These examples illustrate the brutal policy of the Russian Federation, which is contrary to the principles that underpin the European Union. The EU should take joint and decisive action against the practices of the Russian Federation. Given that the Federal Republic of Germany currently has a Presidency of the Council of the European Union, it has a greater responsibility to respect, above all, European solidarity, which is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union. The Federal Government should immediately abandon its vested interests and start to be guided primarily by the EU's interest as a community of Member States. Therefore, the Federal Government decided to stop further construction of the EU-harmful Nord Stream 2 project, which could make the EU dependent on Russian gas.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad Nistor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The current situation in Belarus is not only particularly complicated, but also extremely unclear. One thing is certain, however: the abuse of the authorities against their own citizens. The European Union must provide its full support for stopping abuses, investigating these human rights violations, ensuring freedom of expression and fulfilling democratic aspirations. President Lukashenko has ruled Belarus for 25 years in a pure dictatorial style. Is Russia seeking its definitive compromise or its transformation into a pawn? Moscow's game can be a very complex and lasting one. The stakes are huge for Russia: the Kremlin has been seeking Belarus' economic-political realignment for almost a quarter of a century. The current protests are neither anti-Russia, but neither pro-EU and NATO, and Moscow's interests are obvious. In these circumstances, Russian disinformation can affect us in very subtle and insidous ways. For now, the opposition is very active, but without a coagulated leadership. Leadership is fragmented and amorphous; leaders seem to be aniated by sometimes divergent interests, and some are hovering. My intervention urges solidarity and concrete action by the European Union, built on accurate and complete information, with positive results for both the EU and the Belarusian people.

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR)
text: Writing. – What is happening in Belarus has a retrospective feel for me and certainly for some colleagues. 30 years ago, like the Belarusians, we stood against tinges to win the natural human right to freedom and democracy, against censorship and brutal police violence. Last week we heard the story of Marie Kolesnikove: a Baroque flutist jumps out of a police car and rips her passport to prevent forced eviction from the country. An honor to her heroism and patriotism, which reminded me of my former colleagues from Charter 77. She's in prison, and we have to demand her immediate release. 15 years ago, I used to go to Belarus often and talk to young people who were vividly interested in our experience in 1989. Belarus has a long way to go. It is in a different geopolitical position, which has a significant impact on its future direction. But that's what the demonstrators realize. They understand that they will have to have some balanced and friendly relations with Russia in the future. Russia, too, should understand that any intervention will irreparably damage them. Our task is to support Belarusians where they so wish on the road to greater freedom. Not only sanctions against representatives of the Lukashenko regime and pressure to hold elections under international asylum, but also symbolically: political asylum, medical care, scholarships for young people.

name: President. –
text: Dear colleagues, I think we shouldn’t wait any longer. I was told that the Council is on its way so maybe the Commissioner could prepare to take over first.

name: Didier Reynders
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, permettez-moi d’abord de remercier le Parlement européen d’avoir inscrit ce point à l’ordre du jour de la plénière d’aujourd’hui. C’est l’occasion pour la Commission de faire état de la situation des efforts accomplis et mis en œuvre pour une approche plus coordonnée en matière de restriction de la libre-circulation dans la lutte contre la COVID-19. Depuis le début de la pandémie, les États membres ont adopté une série de mesures en vue de lutter contre la propagation du virus, certaines d’entre elles venant limiter la libre-circulation au sein de l’Union. Ces mesures unilatérales, bien que prises en vue de protéger la santé publique, ont eu pour résultat d’importantes perturbations. The Commission has always stressed that any restrictions to the fundamental right of free movement taken to address public health risks should only be used where strictly necessary, and be coordinated, proportionate and non—discriminatory.  Businesses and citizens have been confronted with diverging measures, often adopted at very short notice and not sufficiently coordinated with other Member States. Many of us have felt this in our daily lives with long queues at the borders and confusion about where we can travel in the EU and under which conditions. Throughout the last months, the Commission has worked closely with the Member States to ensure EU citizens’ rights are respected. We issued several guidelines and communications linked to the pandemic. In a first step, we have successfully addressed challenges, such as blanket restrictions to free movement, but now most Member States have put an end to the controls they at first introduced at their international borders. However, restrictions to free movement persist and in some Member States have even been reinforced. Half a year after the beginning of this crisis, we can no longer afford uncoordinated restrictions to cross-border movement.  Mesdames et Messieurs, nous avons besoin d’une approche plus coordonnée, prévisible et transparente pour prévenir la diffusion du virus et préserver la santé des citoyens et la libre-circulation dans l’Union. Une coordination renforcée est cruciale pour les millions de citoyens qui traversent une frontière intérieure de manière régulière, pour la reconstruction de l’économie européenne et pour éviter les séparations de nombreuses familles de part et d’autre d’une frontière. C’est pour cette raison que, le 4 septembre dernier, la Commission a proposé une recommandation du Conseil pour une approche coordonnée en matière de restriction à la libre circulation. Notre proposition se fonde sur deux principes fondamentaux du droit européen, notamment en matière de libre-circulation: la proportionnalité et la non-discrimination. Ces principes doivent être respectés pour toutes les restrictions adoptées par les États membres. Notre proposition de recommandation met en avant une approche fondée sur quatre points. First, the introduction of common criteria for Member States when deciding whether to introduce restrictions to free movement: the case notification rate, which is the total number of newly notified cases per 100 000 people in a given area in the last 14 days, the test positivity rate, which is the percentage of positive tests among all tests carried out during the last week, and the testing rate, which is the number of tests per 100 000 people carried out during the last week. Second, a common colour code should be used across the Union to provide clarity for all. Third, a common approach should be established when dealing with travellers coming from areas deemed to be at higher risk. Fourth, giving clear, comprehensive and timely information to the public.  We need to step up our communication efforts. Member States should also inform each other and the Commission of any upcoming restriction on a weekly basis. This information should also be regularly provided to the Commission for publication on the reopened EU web platform, which already contains valuable information.  The Commission does not propose any new restrictions or encourage Member States to do so. Instead the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control stresses the importance of general sanitary measures in containing the virus, such as physical distancing and the wearing of masks. However, where a Member State does consider that travel restrictions are essential, the Commission wants to ensure that this is done in a more coordinated way. The decision to introduce such restrictions remains the responsibility of the Member States, which have to comply with EU law. Of course Member States have the possibility not to introduce restrictions at all, even if the different criteria outlined in the draft recommendation are met. We are working closely with the German Presidency and we look forward to the discussion on this proposal. If I may, allow me to add a few words on the Schengen area and the free movement of goods and services. Schengen is a major achievement of the EU and it is a living project. During 35 years of existence, it has faced many challenges that reshaped it, but now Schengen is at risk and not only because of the pandemic. Never before has the Schengen area been put to the test as in the last five years. After the migration crisis of 2015, but also after increased terrorist threats, controls at internal borders sometimes became the new normal. We are determined to change this situation. In the recent Security Union Strategy and in the upcoming New Pact on Migration and Asylum, the Commission is identifying a number of initiatives for a stronger and more complete Schengen, in particular as regards trust-building and efficiency of controls at the external borders. I know that, in addition to free movement of people, free movement of goods and services is a subject that is close to the heart of many in House. In this regard, let me reiterate a message already raised by Commissioner Breton within the Competitiveness Council on 1 September.  We need to ensure free movement of goods and services between Member States to safeguard supply chains. It is essential that all necessary measures are taken for this to become a reality on the ground so that both workers and goods are able to cross borders in less than 15 minutes. And, while our focus today is the smooth functioning of the EU internal market and Schengen, let us bear in mind that European supply chains have to remain connected to global ones, and the unrestricted access of essential transport workers from third countries needs to be upheld as well.  Madame la Présidente, Mesdames, Messieurs, pour conclure, la libre-circulation, l’espace Schengen et le marché intérieur sont parmi les principales réalisations de l’Union et sont d’une importance capitale pour l’économie européenne. Nous avons le devoir, plus que jamais, de les protéger dans cette période de crise. Nous devons travailler ensemble, plus étroitement encore, pour montrer aux citoyens européens qu’en cette période difficile, l’Union européenne est présente pour préserver leur santé ainsi que leurs droits et libertés. Nous travaillons de manière très étroite, je l’ai dit, avec la présidence allemande sur ces sujets et je vous remercie, évidemment, d’avoir inscrit ce point à l’ordre du jour. Je serai très heureux d’entendre vos observations et, si possible, de répondre à vos questions.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I apologise for letting you wait, but I had a conversation with your President, Mr Sassoli. It took a little longer, so I had to hurry here. But in a proven collegiality, this works very well between the Commission and the Council, and not only on this issue. I am grateful to you for having the opportunity today to share a few thoughts with you on an issue that does not only move Members, not only the representatives of the Council and the Commission, but what moves all people. These days, we are all feeling that the serious crisis is not over. In almost all the Member States of the European Union, the figures are rising dramatically. It is about nothing less than the protection of citizens. All of us – the institutions – have an equal obligation to do everything possible to ensure the best possible protection of people's health. If what we keep saying is true, not only here in the European Parliament, that the virus does not have a passport and that the virus does not care about national borders, then we must also develop the right action from these very simple findings. After a few difficult weeks, at the beginning of the crisis, we managed to draw the right conclusions by saying that solidarity is the order of the day. In the meantime, we are helping with the equipment with medical goods and technical equipment. We have developed procedures to ensure that all people, regardless of which EU country they live in, can be better cared for. However, as far as the immediate consequences of combating the pandemic are concerned, we have not yet reached the point where we can all say: coordination, coordination, voting is working. That is why the German EU Presidency has decided to put the issue of coordinating our actions on the agenda. Once again, thank you for having to discuss this here in Parliament today. They all come from very different countries, and you know that the reactions to the crisis are very different. We are currently struggling in the Council with the fact that we do not know exactly whether all ministers can attend the physical meetings. In some cases, the national measures taken are so restrictive that ministers cannot travel. I am here now, and that means to me that if I return on Thursday, I will have to be quarantined for several days and I will have to be tested several times. This in turn makes it more difficult in other areas. I'll be back next week. So it has a very practical effect, but I don't want to talk about politicians now, I want to talk about what people experience every day. As Didier Reynders has already mentioned, we have sometimes had very painful experiences from the reintroduction of border controls in the border regions. In the beginning, everyone called for this. We must protect the citizens. But after a short time it became clear that the reintroduction of border controls also brings with it considerable difficulties.  That is why two messages in your direction, honourable Members, are important to me. On the one hand, it remains the prerogability of the Member States to take the necessary measures necessary and appropriate to protect public health. Whether these are the quarantine requirements, whether these are tests, whether they are travel restrictions or whether this is the introduction of temporary controls. But – and this is my second message – all the measures taken by the Member States, and I am speaking for the Member States now, must be proportionate and non-discriminatory and must comply with EU law. And a good dose of pragmatism is also required. In the end, the restrictive measures must also be practicable and they must not interfere too much with people's everyday lives. At all political levels, the Council is currently working towards closer coordination. Next week, for example, the Ministers for Europe will also be discussing this, so it is not just the ministers responsible for health that will seek an exchange on this. Because we know that it has massive political consequences. I would like to give a few examples of where we have already made progress. On 30 June, for example, the Council adopted a recommendation on the gradual lifting of the temporary restriction on non-essential travel to the EU. We have also stated that we are committed to the epidemiological assess the situation in various third countries in such a way that this can then also be coordinated throughout the EU. On 4 September, we convened an ad hoc meeting of health ministers to find a basic understanding of what common quarantine, what a common testing regime within the EU might look like and how this should also be brought into line with the competences of the Member States.  Ministers responsible for the single market will also exchange views on how to remove unnecessary internal market barriers later this week. We will, of course, also call on the Member States not to create new obstacles. We will probably also call on the Commission once again to learn the appropriate lessons from the COVID-19 crisis, so that we are better prepared for future crises.  I hope that we will also be able to propose a series of new measures, in close coordination, to make the internal market more resilient.  Finally, we are all familiar with the Commission's latest proposal: the famous traffic light system. With a colour coding system, we want to help once again in the classification of risk areas to make decisions more transparent. It is clear that this is not a separate decision by a single Member State, but that, in a European Union committed to openness and transparency, it always has the appropriate effects on the other Member States. It also involves measures to return to areas of increased risk. I had already mentioned my modest personal example. We have achieved a great deal. However, I believe that it is important now – the crisis is not over – that we learn from the weaknesses, that we move even closer together, that we also bring the positive examples to the fore in our discussion and that, in the end, freedom of movement, freedom, transparency and the lack of frontiers, for which the European Union stands first and foremost, do not suffer lasting damage. This should be a common interest between Parliament, the Commission and, of course, the Council.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, Minister. Thank you for these clear messages. I think it is gratifying to see in the European Parliament that you are pulling together and that the messages you are sending today are so clear. However, I would like to tell you that, in reality, I do not believe that everything you are presenting to us here today has yet arrived. The people of the border areas, the citizens who have to travel professionally or privately, have not yet experienced so much of the new world of coordination that has been invoked today.  You will experience several copies on domestic flights, which have to be completed in different languages. They note that not all countries make the same classifications as the risk zones are really cut, and they note that border closures are still part of the arsenal of member states that have been so praised. That is why, Minister, Commissioner, I think that, in the interests of the citizens – for which we all work – we must make it clear that freedom and freedom of movement in Europe must not be restricted again here. That was understandable at the beginning of the crisis, but now the Member States have learned. It is now up to all politicians to ensure that the people in the border areas who keep the internal market alive do not become a testing laboratory for the learning process of the Member States. Of course, we know that the Corona crisis is an unprecedented challenge – for all of us. However, it is all the more important that the Council and the Member States now commit themselves together to follow the path that you have described here. I believe that when we, today and tomorrow, as the European Parliament, declare that the open internal market and open borders and tests must be the principles as a means of bordering, but not nationality as a means of control, then we are doing what we need, namely paving the way for a European path in the fight against the virus. I think we are all interested in that.

name: Sara Cerdas
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, nine months of an unprecedented pandemic, we are now going through a chronic phase of risk management. In nine months and, despite the efforts of the European institutions, we have seen a real lack of coordination between member states. I would remind you that public health is a shared competence between all Member States and the Union and must always respect the fundamental rights of European citizens.  It is therefore urgent to create a genuine European Health Union. This is one of the greatest needs felt in the course of this pandemic. We need effective, coordinated and shared management in order to ensure that European citizens are confident in their authorities at the most diverse levels. The Commission with the opinion of the ECDC should promote with the Member States a common methodology for data collection with the standardisation of case and death definitions by COVID-19. Only then will we be able to harmonise risk assessment across the Union. There is an urgent need to develop a common framework of public health measures to be adopted by the authorities in view of the different levels of risk, thereby enabling citizens to better understand and understand and support. Only with effective coordination can we ensure an efficient and resilient single market that ensures the availability of products throughout the European Union and for all its citizens.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, European citizens have been exemplary in their fight against COVID-19. They bravely faced a serious health threat. They paid the heavy economic, social and psychological toll of confinement. They have been caught all summer in chaos at the internal borders of the European Union, subject to unilateral decisions to control or restrict traffic on the basis of disparate mapping and mutual non-recognition of biological tests. Yesterday tourists, tomorrow cross-border workers, students, artists. This disorganization will have health but also economic, scientific and cultural repercussions. Freedom of movement within the Schengen area cannot be constantly threatened. The health crisis should not be used as an excuse for national selfishness and lack of solidarity. Commissioner, the European Union must quickly adopt common epidemiological criteria and comparable colour codes, we have seen that we are on the right track. Mr Minister for European Affairs, there is an urgent need for a consultation with your counterparts on joint and, if possible, common health recommendations. It is not a question of budget, it is a question of political will. European citizens are looking at us, they want more than a juxtaposition of national health measures, they are calling for a real European public health policy.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have heard from the Commissioner that we need a more coordinated approach to COVID: well, it is mid-September! Let's say with the timing you're not really on the piece! The European Union has been non-existent and ineffective.  I give you a short photograph: each country manages the health emergency independently; there is no coordination with the European Union and often not with neighbouring countries either; borders are closed without any kind of clear logic; quarantines are imposed differently from one State to another; there is no clarity as to when and to whom to make tampons; the fortnight of quarantine for positives is now also under discussion. I mean, total chaos. You said, Commissioner, that we need to introduce common lines: well awake! We are at a paradox. I heard first from the European Council that, in short, they are doing hard work with meetings and meetings on COVID. It is a pity that they are the same people who, in the midst of the pandemic, cut EUR 7.7 billion on the health programme: targets for improving the European health system are disappearing, therefore.  As far as immigration is concerned, Italy, thanks to the unworthy government, supports the arrival of thousands of immigrants, many positive to COVID. The European Union cares. There is no common assistance, there is no distribution of refugees, there is no solidarity. In short, the borders are there for everyone except Italy, which is forced to take new health risks.  I will conclude: your inability is simply proof that this Europe is not working.

name: Petra De Sutter
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, many EU citizens craved holidays this summer and some did go on holidays, to Spain for instance. After their holidays, Belgian tourists returning from Spain faced 14 days of quarantine. Dutch tourists only faced 10 days, and French (tourists) zero. For us Belgians, Spain is a red zone in its entirety, but not so for the French authorities.  We cannot explain these diverging practices to our citizens. It creates an idea of arbitrariness amongst our citizens, while it is very important that everyone keeps following the guidelines. It does not make sense from a health perspective. All EU citizens are equal, also in the eyes of the virus. A Dutch person who visits a Spanish village faces the same risk of infection as a Greek, Swedish or Slovakian person who went to the same village. It also does not make sense from an internal market perspective. It creates uncertainties for businesses and cross-border workers if Member States apply different quarantine lengths or definitions of essential travel.  Luckily, the Commission indeed proposed earlier this month that Member States would use common criteria and thresholds to base their travel restrictions on. As a parliament we should support this. Member States should follow the ECDC’s recommendations and agree on common rules for returning travellers, identical colour coding and common criteria. I hope that all Member States can agree on a common viewpoint on this matter in the interest of all EU citizens. (Applause)

name: Geert Bourgeois
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we have quite rightly stressed that public health is a member state competence, even a sub-state competence in our case. It's got to stay that way. The policy, the choices, the funding must remain there. The EU has no harmonising power, that is what the Treaty says. Where can the EU add value?  Well, firstly by coordinating the colour codes: quickly achieving the same colour codes in all Member States. We have seen the same zone in France being red and in Belgium being coloured orange. Those codes also give the same meaning. Secondly, maximum security of movement of people and goods. Our crown jewel, the single market, and the Schengen zone must be safeguarded. Thirdly, it is also good that the Commission is taking the lead in the procurement of vaccine programmes. I want reliable information on this: on the test, the results, the progress.  But I also ask the Commission to be transparent about the purchase contracts with the farmareuzen, to be transparent about the negotiating teams. I have requested the information from the Commissioner in the context of public administration. I'm waiting for the answer to that. The Commission demands transparency, often shows transparency. Well, show that you have nothing to hide: practice what you preach.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, it must be acknowledged openly that we have completely wasted the last three months. Because what is happening today in cross-border and what our citizens, passengers, workers, but also companies are experiencing on a daily basis is simply unbelievable. The lion's share of all this, of course, lies primarily with the Member States and their governments, Minister, which have shown zero willingness to cooperate and, at the same time, hold key competences in this area, as has been said. However, the Commission also has a big butter on its head: how is it possible that it has only just put forward proposals on cross-border movement and cooperation? Did you really think we solved everything in June? In a united Europe, how is it possible for the authorities of some Member States to refuse to recognise to a Citizen of the European Union any kind of COVID-19 test carried out in another Member State? Do laboratories and doctors in each Member State operate to different standards or are menial tests used? And Belgium is an example of this, you come to Belgium and the test of another country is simply not recognized by anyone.  Why is there still no harmonised methodology for collecting and evaluating the number of infected persons, nor a harmonised methodology for 'traffic lights'? Due to these lack of methodologies, data on infected people are misrevalued, which in turn leads Member States to make erroneous changes in their traffic lights and so on and so on and so on. Colleagues, Europe just needs to wake up! If we do not now come to our senses and show the added value of European integration in time, the European Union as we know it will end up distrustful of its own people. I hope that the resolution that we are all working on together will also contribute to the fact that we will all wake up and that this resolution will be seen both on the Council side and on the Commission side not as something from the European Parliament, but as a document with which it must start working, because it contains the views of European citizens.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Madam President, the European Union has shown that it blindly listens to the new order of things, which pre-defines how we live and how we move for the rest of our lives. I have been listening to the speeches that have been going on all this time and I have not heard any debate on the most basic. Why don't we say that people are now losing their fundamental rights, the simple, human daily freedoms that they had claimed and won for so many years? We have now entered a process in which no one can speak and no one can question the position of the corovirus. But we cannot judge all of this when we see things other than what is happening and what they want to go through. The one minute I have only to speak is minimal, and I will dwell on one characteristic fact: Some time ago a company started which wants to get a vaccine. We in Greece, and I as a Member of the European Parliament, have asked the European Parliament to tell us why this company has consulted the leaders of at least 25 European states, so that no one can prosecute it in the event of a side effect. I have not received any response, no one has dared to talk to me, until the company itself stopped at some point to take out this vaccine and do experiments, because it said that the side effects are too unbearable. We cannot therefore talk about humanism in the European Union when a child cannot see his father or his mother dying, and cannot go to hospital on the grounds of COVID-19. And there's also no autopsies on the victims. There's a fairy tale they're trying to impose on us.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I've been really worried about the last few days. In June and July we had made it. The number of people infected was very, very low in almost all European countries, and we actually had Corona under control. Now the figures are exploding in many parts of Europe, and unfortunately we are also seeing additional deaths in some countries. Autumn and winter, with the fact that the coronavirus spreads more easily in enclosed spaces – eighteen times lighter – are just around the corner. That is why we need targeted measures and we need joint action. After all, the acceptance of the population for what we decide to contain will not be increased if every country does something different and no one sees through it any more. And only then will we build trust. Finally, a sentence to the colleague from the right, who has unfortunately left her place now. It has been said that there was no European solidarity. So, we have all not worked well enough, and Ursula von der Leyen has rightly apologised to Italy. But to say that there has been no solidarity is a mockery of the nurses and many others who have taken in patients and saved lives, including in other European countries. We must not let that go under the table.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: –Madam President, we can win the battle against the corona, but if we are going to do it, we have to do it together, together, the events of spring have shown us. Try to remember back to spring, specifically the beginning of March. The corona epidemic was raging in Europe, we had miles of long queues at border crossings and millions of Europeans were plunged into uncertainty. Uncertainty as to whether they became ill, when they could visit their family again on the other side of the border, but also in relation to whether they could get the food they needed. When I look back at that time, fortunately we've come a long way. We have succeeded in ensuring that goods can circulate freely in Europe. We have succeeded in making joint purchases of medicines and aids, and we have agreed to keep our hands under each other with historically large aid packages. We have coordinated all this in the European Union and this has helped to allay the uncertainty that has been going on, but we are not on target yet. We need to do more, and the corona crisis has also shown us that we have some weaknesses. We still have platforms that sell dangerous goods online without them being removed. We still have airlines that have not repaid money to customers, nor do we have mutual recognition of cross-border corona tests. There are still a great many things we need to do and we need to do them, because otherwise we do not have a well-functioning internal market and what we need.  On the other hand, I also know that if we want to, we can do things, at least if we do it together.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – President Barley, Commissioner Reynders, Minister Roth, a few weeks ago, I looked in dismay as for a European country all the other European countries were red areas. For another, only certain areas were red, and Brussels itself was red for other European countries. Different countries have different definitions of what a Covid case means and what a red zone means. I ask you, what kind of Union is that "red" means something in Berlin, something in Brussels and something else in Bucharest. In the midst of this health crisis, the European Union must speak with one voice. After what happened in February, in March, in April, the European citizen no longer accepts hesitations from us. Populism and misinformation feed on our clumsiness. Maya Angelou said, "when you know more you should do more." Now I think we know more than we do in April, and to do more today is to create a unified language for this crisis and common measures for the Member States. Herr Roth, Sie müssen nicht nur uns überzeugen. Sie müssen als Minister handeln.  The time of the experts has passed, the experts have expressed themselves, it is necessary for health ministers to make political decisions.

name: Virginie Joron (ID).
text: Madam President, the consequences of COVID, let us talk about it. Protocol 6, single article: '[t]he European Parliament is based in Strasbourg"." That is what is enshrined in the European treaties. However, at the last minute, MEPs were asked to come to Brussels, with twice as many new cases of COVID-19. Yet Strasbourg was ready. However, strict measures have been put in place in taxis, hotels, restaurants and pedestrian streets. Work has even been done in Parliament this summer. But we know that the majority of French Green MEPs vote against Strasbourg. However, Brussels has been classified as a red zone since August and you have given in under pressure from the Greens and Socialists who have never liked to come to Strasbourg because they live in Brussels. Using coronavirus or CO2 emissions to blow up the Strasbourg headquarters is unacceptable. When you commit to a mandate, you respect the law and the law says that the seat of the European Parliament is in Strasbourg for 12 periods of sessions. We want 2021 to make up for this loss for Strasbourg. Before we give a European roadmap, let us set an example here by respecting the treaties.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, it is true that we are experiencing unprecedented confusion. As you said, there was no coordination or harmonization. We have seen it on the tests, we have seen it on the common criteria, even for the assessment of the number of deaths, and we also see it on European classification and mapping by colour. We have even seen it recently, with regard to quarantine, since it varies between 7, 10 and 14 days. It is very important to harmonize these elements. We have the ECDC recommendations and I think Member States must follow those recommendations. There is also confusion about the Transparency of the Commission. We have learned that there are eight negotiators, who contract with laboratories but do not want to be named after us. This is completely abnormal because we want to verify the links or conflicts of interest between the negotiators and the pharmaceutical companies. We want access to markets and we are told that they are private markets. This is public money that we give to laboratories! In addition, we want to know how much we give to each lab. We also want to know the responsibility for side effects. Who is responsible: laboratories where Member States? Finally, we cannot build trust if we do not have access to clinical studies before marketing authorization. This is how trust is restored.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the economic losses caused by restrictions on mobility have been enormous for many sectors, especially tourism and hospitality. Neither the calls to the Commission to lift these checks nor the RE-open EU website have been sufficient, as we remain without agreements between the Member States. There are no common health assessment criteria, nor legal certainty mechanisms for welcoming travellers and workers. We have found ourselves from disparate risk ratings in the absence of recognition of diagnostic tests, which force the imposing of illogical quarantines: ten days, fourteen days, seven days. This lack of coordination and seriousness has led to an unprecedented fall in tourism, a sector of which many families live in Spain. Your situation is unsustainable today.  All this highlights the need for harmonised measures to ensure, on the one hand, the functioning of the Schengen area and, on the other hand, the exercise of the sovereignty of the Member States in the protection of the health of citizens.  Since last May we have been asking for action in this regard. This situation was foreseeable and you continue to be eningd with winning and winning competitions, as this Resolution demonstrates, rather than working on practical and effective solutions.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I obviously welcome the fact that some attempt is now being made to coordinate the COVID response, but it’s pretty incredible that we’re six months into the most serious pandemic in living memory, in one of the richest regions in the world, with a massive institutional bureaucracy and we’re only getting around to it now. We cannot even compare COVID statistics because of the different arrangements in place in Member States. So is it any wonder that EU citizens are looking on in disbelief.  This is a single virus so why are there so many different responses? People want to follow the rules, but it’s difficult when the rules change and when they are inconsistent. The ECDC all along advised against border controls, but they were ignored, and the problem, you see, is that what it needed was a politically coordinated response, but it didn’t come. It needed solidarity, but you can’t develop solidarity overnight. There was no solidarity when Irish single mothers paid the price of Munich stockholders in the financial crisis and no solidarity for the thousands of desperate migrants on the Greek island, so it’s no wonder there was no solidarity on COVID. It’s an awful pity we’re coming to this situation now, but I hope we learned the lessons of it.

name: Daniela Rondinelli (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, six months after the pandemic, we in the European Parliament are rightly calling for greater coordination of Member States in the fight against COVID. The Union has shown great ambition and great political will with the agreement on the resources of the Recovery Fund and EU Next Generation, but there can be no recovery unless the Member States extend the same approach to the other aspects: health, labour, the free movement of persons and workers; otherwise there is a risk of blocking the internal market. European coordination is therefore essential in order to strengthen traceability capacity, including by setting up rapid tests before embarkation on aircraft, ships and trains; we must set the same quarantine times and establish equal penalties for infected people who do not comply with the rules of isolation. We in the 5-Star Movement believe that the Commission and the Council can no longer hide behind the excuse of the competences laid down in the Treaties for not acting, because we do not have time for their overall reform. Instead, they must demonstrate that political will to redefine the health treaties and an agreement on the social and welfare model that Europe urgently needs.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think it is very easy to know what we have to do now. When we were taken by surprise by the pandemic it was difficult and chaos ensnared. Even so, the Commission, at the time, wanted to coordinate the closure of borders and restrictions. It was the Member States and their governments that did not want to.  Now it is simple: harmonise criteria throughout the Union area, define restrictions by regions and not by Member State and have exactly the same conditions in green areas, yellow areas, orange areas, red zones.  This is not difficult to do and it is the way to save Schengen and save Schengen in three respects: the aspect of health, the aspect of the internal market and the aspect of citizens' rights. This time they are not in conflict. They converge if we are able to have a coordinated response given by the Council. The answer is in the hands of the governments of the 27 Member States.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Corona in the Schengen area. Just three months ago, we discussed here how important it is to coordinate travel restrictions at European level and to preserve the Schengen area. But the patchwork of border closures at that time has now become an almost impersible labyrinth. A labyrinth of green, yellow and red zones, unfounded measures, inconsistent criteria where the same region is classified by one state as a yellow region and by the other as a green region. I therefore urge the Council to standardise these criteria and measures. Create the security and confidence that our citizens and our economy need at this time! I expect common solutions to common challenges and, under no circumstances, a next wave of national solo actions that will ultimately harm everyone.

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, even before COVID’s start protectionism was on the rise, globally and in Europe. COVID has clearly intensified the protectionist mind-set in Europe and has forced EU citizens to think once again in terms of national borders. Is France a red zone or orange zone? Will I be allowed to go to Denmark from Belgium without having quarantine? We must fight these base nationalist tendencies that would be fundamentally negative to all of us. While protecting health must be our first priority, this crisis must not be used as an excuse for actions against the single market. The single market has been fundamental in improving the competitiveness of our economies and prosperity for our citizens. The four freedoms are what make the European Union real. The pandemic has made it necessary to rethink many of our policies, but it doesn’t mean rethinking our values. The EU has grown and prospered thanks to its values of openness and free trade, and we must make sure that our actions are not undermined.

name: Georg Mayer (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what fairy tales have not we all heard when it comes to the Schengen borders. In 2015, for example, it was said, for God's sake, that internal border controls could not be introduced within the Schengen area. This is illegal for the EU.  What are we experiencing now? We are now witnessing the exact chaotic opposite of what was said at the time. And what else are we experiencing now, ladies and gentlemen? We are witnessing the restriction of freedom of movement in Europe with full intent. And what else do we experience, ladies and gentlemen? We are witnessing political scaremongering among a large part of European governments.  The Austrian Federal Government, which illegally disregards the Austrian Federal Constitution internally and is unlawful to the outside world when it comes to freedom of movement, is particularly prominent. I think that Article 7 of the EU Treaty could well be considered. This COVID pandemic shows once again the uncoordinatedness and weaknesses of this Schengen area. There is an urgent need for us to remove this patchwork that the citizens unfortunately see every day today and to bring together sensible coordination.

name: Anna Cavazzini (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In the spring, I had the feeling that Europe was tearing us between our hands. The trees went up again, and the military stood on the german-Polish border, families and friends were torn apart, the internal market was disrupted, and border commuters could no longer work. This must not happen again, ladies and gentlemen, because a borderless Europe is one of the greatest achievements. But we are currently seeing a patchwork of travel warnings and border measures. I do not feel that the Commission and the Member States have learned from the spring. Instead of this chaos, we need to coordinate health measures and travel warnings. Only by acting together can we contain this virus. The Commission has finally made a proposal for coordinated border management in the Schengen area. But a lot of precious time has been lost in the summer. That is why this proposal must now be implemented quickly by the Council and applied by the Member States. One thing is still very important to me personally, because I am also affected by it. Whether at external borders or within the EU, freedom of movement must also apply to binational unmarried couples, because love is not tourism.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the virus is one and attacks us all without distinction. And far from uniting for defeat we have suffered how each Member State adopts restrictions on the free movement of persons and goods without coordination between all countries, nor with the European Union. This lack of harmonisation causes chaos, uncertainty and misinformation among European citizens; fragments the internal market and also blocks the Schengen area.  We therefore need the Commission and the Council to urgently and effectively establish harmonised measures to rebuild trust between all Member States and European citizens; that the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control provides the official data for infected, deceased and mapping, and that it also establishes the same health criteria for all Member States, especially on the basis of areas or regions and not entire countries.  We need tests at all airports and accesses to restore the free movement of people, without additional barriers and always protecting the health of all. It is essential for all, citizens and businesses, that people and goods can move freely and safely throughout the European Union.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Covid-19 has hit Europe very hard. Not least, many people have been hit hard during the health crisis through illness, and relatives have been hit hard after too many deaths. We also know that people suffer from the restrictions and restrictions imposed, sometimes rightly, but sometimes, unfortunately, these have been tools that have gone in the wrong direction. I do not want to contribute to any one-sided blackpainting of what has been done. I think that the way the EU has reacted and how the Member States have tried to act have been important political tools for preventing the pandemic from spreading. People have been there, too. The health sector has made heroic efforts. Doctors have helped patients across national borders. However, there are things that we should be careful about – we have already seen tendencies not only towards protectionism, but also to populism in the spirit of the crisis. We must not take this direction for the future. I am one of those who really want to protect freedom of movement and who look with great concern at how people now find it difficult to travel between our countries and cross our borders. I am thinking of a young generation of students who may not dare to take the step of studying in another country. It can have far-reaching consequences for Europe when freedom of movement is attacked.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The epidemiological situation has been unfavourable in many EU Member States in recent times, and a number of people, including my country Hungary, have decided to reintroduce measures that have already been successfully applied. The issue of border closures has been raised several times in recent weeks. I would like to state that I consider the concerns to be completely unfounded, as the restrictions on border traffic and entry do not go beyond what is strictly necessary to avert the threat set out in the Schengen Borders Code. Each Member State shall be responsible for taking measures concerning the border closure which it considered appropriate. Harmonisation cannot be a solution because of the slow pace of the EU institutions. During the second wave, the protection of people's health and life is paramount and, on the basis of experience, only the Member States can adequately ensure protection. Thank you very much!

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, Mr Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you first of all for sharing your views on the situation but above all your concerns, because the COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact, as you have recalled, on our lives. It has changed the way we live, work and travel and our relationships with family and friends. No one has escaped its consequences. First of all, I would like to point out that the Commission responded quickly, from the beginning of the pandemic, to the call of a large number of citizens, businesses and public authorities. It has made significant efforts for rapid and close coordination between Member States in all areas, including and especially in those that have a direct impact on the lives of citizens. In particular, the Commission has adopted a series of guidelines and recommendations on border management and free movement. Of course, I heard Mr. Schwab, Ms. Trillet-Lenoir and Ms. De Sutter talk about free movement. As of March 30, there were recommendations on border workers, seasonal and self-employed, particularly in difficulty. From the outset, proposals for coordination have been put forward and these efforts must continue and above all intensify so that we can better protect the single market and the freedom of movement to which, as we know, European citizens are deeply attached. The lack of coordination means that we must now do everything we can to win or regain the trust of the citizens. That is why, I repeat, from the beginning and again this summer, the Commission has taken initiatives, since from the beginning of August, without wasting time, when the new situations appeared in a number of Member States, efforts were made to strengthen a clearly deficient coordination. On 7 August, we sent a letter to all Member States reminding them of the applicable principles for restricting free movement. This letter was followed by a technical document further elaborating on some of these principles. And I would like to make it clear on a number of points, depending on the questions, that with regard to mutual recognition of tests, Mrs Cerdas' recommendation, in particular, goes in this direction and also calls for this mutual recognition of the tests. Similarly, we are working on a common method of data collection; Mrs. Koneon alluded to it. Common methods have already been provided by the European Centre for this collection of tests at national level. From now on, work continues to do the same at the regional level. I would also like to clarify the situation with regard to vaccines. I have seen the question from Mr Bourgeois and Ms Rivasi about that and first of all we have a robust, now complete, portfolio with six promising vaccine candidates. I want to say that we are also in more advanced discussions with one because one agreement has been signed was with AstraZeneca on 27 August. The vaccines will have to meet all the necessary safety requirements and to be approved by the European Medicines Agency and the Product Liability Directive remains fully in force. The agreements allow Member States to indemnify the manufacturer but patents and consumer rights remain fully in force so we are continually applying the same rules and perhaps some comments on two other issues that I heard during these discussions.  I want to insist on the fact that citizens who exercise their right of free movement, Ms Cavazzini, and their family members are exempt from the travel restrictions currently in place. As EU citizens who have not exercised their right to free movement, we know that several Schengen states also allow entry for unmarried partners. We have repeatedly encouraged the remaining Member States to follow this broad interpretation of the free movement of rules in order to give unmarried couples the possibility to reunite after months of separation, so it's important to insist on that. This is not of course about Hungary. We have sent a letter to the Ministers of Justice and the Ministers of the Interior to know what are the reasons for a possible differentiation between some nationals and others. I'm thinking about the countries of the Visegrad Group and so of course we try to understand why it's possible to make such a differentiation. We have received a response and will analyze that, but you know that we don't want to have discrimination between different national people at the EU level and it is not a discussion for the moment about Hungary. To conclude, I want to go back to the proposal for a recommendation sent to the German Presidency and to the Council. In fact On 4 September, we adopted this proposal for a recommendation in favour of a coordinated approach which would, in particular, offer common criteria and a common colour code to draw a common map at European level on the basis of the same criteria and would allow better access to information for all stakeholders. This is also in line with the idea of communicating once a week about changes in measures that could take place depending on the evolution of the map. The Commission, of course, remains available to work closely with the Member States and, as I said, with the German Presidency of the Council to advance our joint efforts in this direction.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to express my sincere thanks for this strong appeal for better coordination, for closer cooperation, for the principle of mutual learning and coexistence. However, I would also ask you to be fair. None of us – neither you nor I, nor anyone else – had a master plan or blueprint in the drawer to act in retrospect as needed and possibly better in retrospect.  If a Member of Parliament, whom I highly esteem, who comes from the same country as me, makes demands on the European Union – and in particular on the Council – Mrs Sippel, then I would like to share my experience in a federal country such as Germany, where we are not even able to bring about uniform rules for 16 Länder. So your ambition, which I share in principle, is already reaching its limits in federally organised countries. And there are reasons for that. These may be mostly reasons that we all do not share together. But there are also reasons to think about at least once. For one thing, i am very grateful for this, the situation in the border regions is particularly dramatic, because we have felt one thing that borders, which no longer play any role at all in people's everyday lives – even in the everyday life of the economy – suddenly lead to a great deal of pain when they are reintroduced, in fact, through border controls. This is perhaps somewhat different in countries that do not maintain this close cooperation in the border regions. A total of 186 000 people have died in or with Corona in the European Union.
