A great tragedy. However, we have reacted very differently. Germany has taken a different path from Italy and France, partly because in parts of Italy and France the pandemic has raged quite differently from what we have done most of the time. Sweden has taken a completely different path. Science is arguing, and that is reassuring, because there are no absolute certainties.  And so I have a problem with your accusation that we have wasted time. Yes, it may have taken too long at one point or another, and I would also like to assure you, honourable Members, Madam President, that we must also achieve better coordination on the basis of the Commission's recommendation, which is a very important basis for us. Because as long as there is no vaccine, we have no certainty as to whether this path or the path taken is the better one.  And the fact that the subject is so emotionally charged has to do above all with the fact that it is really about human lives, about the protection of human lives. And I did not want to defend the Member States in any way. I just wanted to make it clear that we all feel this doubt in us, no matter which Member State we come from.  Once again, however, it is important that we learn from this crisis and that we do not abandon the principles of the internal market, that we do not abandon the principles of Schengen, but that we try to bring the necessary health protection into line with what makes Europe at its core. In this respect, the debate here has been extremely helpful, including for further discussions in the Council. Once again, i would like to thank all those who have spoken. We take this very seriously and I would be very pleased to see this dialogue with you continue.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 September 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marc Angel (S&D)
text: in writing. – With acknowledging the fact that in several Member States COVID-19 cases have increased significantly since the beginning of summer, we also must declare that the restrictions some Members States put in place have not been in line with the actual risk level. Such as closing the Hungarian borders at time of low infection rates. The four freedoms, including the free movement of people, goods and services are essential for a well-functioning internal market. Uncoordinated, unilateral decisions of the Member States are strongly fragmenting the internal market. We cannot expect from citizens or businesses to be able to comply with so diverse measures (such as quarantine for 7, 10 or 14 days; different traveller locator forms; different country ‘colours’; different measures on mask use obligations etc.). Especially when those are also rapidly changing and not always announced well in advance. Beside preserving the integrity of the internal market and also the Schengen area we need: to harmonise restrictive measures, based on data provided by ECDC; common colour code and regional approach at risk mapping; mutual recognition of PCR results in Member States; a harmonised ‘EU traveller locator form’ and to rebuild trust between Member States.

name: Pablo Arias Echeverría (PPE)
text: in writing. – We are faced with a challenge of dimensions never seen before and which requires the coordination of all Member States. Cooperation and understanding are the basis of the European project, and that is precisely what this joint resolution seeks to enhance.  For months we have seen unilateral measures by some Member States, such as discrepancies in the designation of at-risk areas or countries and even in applicable health measures (such as quarantines). If the virus doesn't understand borders, neither should we.  More than ever, we must be united in the fight against coronavirus. We must see it as an opportunity to emerge reinforced from this crisis and be better prepared for future similar events. This is the message conveyed by this Joint Resolution and from here we call on the Member States to take a good note.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The coronavirus pandemic has caused unprecedented shock to both the European and global economies and has had a significant impact on the lives of almost all citizens in the world. After several months of fighting the virus, we have partially succeeded in adapting to a new reality, but at the same time there is a great need for better coordination between Member States.  There is no doubt that what both businesses and citizens need in this particular situation is predictability. The single market or the Schengen area are our european achievements and we must make every effort to ensure that they can function in a secure and stable manner.  The lack of predictability and clear rules on how to combat the pandemic at European level creates uncertainty and a decrease in european confidence, the need to abstain from decisions and creates unnecessary costs. I therefore call for harmonised action between Member States to combat the coronavirus pandemic.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Just a few months ago, many people in Europe thought that the worst moments of the Covid-19 pandemic were behind us. Meanwhile, in recent weeks, we have seen an increase in the number of cases and, consequently, increasing pressure on the health service.  Has the Commission made good use of the calmer holiday period to prepare for the second wave of the crisis? Is it prepared to coordinate the actions of individual Member States in order to avoid chaos and take care of the interests of the most vulnerable citizens?  I call on the Commission, in close cooperation with the Council and the individual Member States, to urgently strengthen coordination on restrictions directly affecting freedom of movement. Key constraints for people moving to do their jobs and support their families. It is also unacceptable that these persons are still waiting for a transparent and harmonised criterion for assessing the epidemiological situation, which, in its current absence, makes it difficult to decide whether to travel responsibly.  Finally, I warn the Commission and the Council against being tempted to pass on the costs of compulsory tests to citizens travelling and travelling for purposes essential such as studies or because of strictly professional responsibilities, e.g. drivers or flight crew. There can be no agreement on additional costs for already highly experienced European citizens, especially if they result from omissions at Commission and Council level.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament, after the first shock of the pandemic, demanded in good time, as early as the spring, through its Committees and in plenary resolutions, coordination of the opening of borders in view of the tourist season. We predicted that, without coordination, the result would be disastrous. President Sassoli reiterated this two weeks ago. Unfortunately, the European Commission ignored us and remained a passive observer. Just last week he made a late attempt at coordination. The European Commission has shown undue inertia, resulting in great suffering for thousands of travellers and, unfortunately, the resurgence of the pandemic in many parts of Europe. The chaos that still prevails today must be stopped immediately. Simple, proportionate and effective rules need to be put in place for everyone. All citizens, regardless of where they live or travel, must know clearly what is going on throughout Europe. And it is necessary for the Commission to coordinate and support the Member States in order to properly implement these rules. The health-economic crisis is here and it's going to last. Only uniform rules can provide an effective response to tackling the pandemic.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – The COVID-19 crisis has clearly shown that EU countries need to work more together on a number of issues, rather than unilaterally delivering. It is also important that all countries follow them when establishing common measures. The consequences of unilateral steps were only seen in the recent past in the EU in the case of unilateral decisions to close national borders, which crippled Schengen and which continues today with Hungary, which has refused entry to nationals of other EU countries. There could also be, for example, a common understanding of flight rules so that there is no situation where flight restrictions are artificially created. To this end, 27 Member States will need to work much more hard to achieve common positions.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. – Dear President, honourable Presidents of the Council and the Commission, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Neym. The European Commission has recently published eu Council recommendations on the restriction of free movement to prevent a Covid-19 pandemic, which provides for the introduction of uniform criteria for restrictions on the movement of persons in EU Member States. Although the recommendations are intended to reduce the negative impact of a pandemic on national economies, such a common and simplified approach would be contrary to the stricter criteria set by individual countries, including Latvia, developed by local specialists with a deeper and more detailed understanding of the health of their citizens. It is not permissible to identify a universal solution without assessing the individual capacities of the Member States, including the capacity of the healthcare system. It is also not justified to determine the specific status of non-self-isolation requirements, the seasonal workforce, as well as diplomats and employees of international institutions, since neither the status nor the position to function constitute immunity from the virus. The Latvian Government should use this pandemic time to take care of inviting its citizens to return to Latvia, using both EU financial resources and the freening of fiscal frames for this purpose. For Latvia, this is an opportunity to change the migratory flow of disadvantaged citizens and improve the demographic situation in the country. This document will be only recommended. I have high hopes for the Latvian Government that it will be able to choose the best possible protection for its citizens, looking not only at the economic but also all other criteria.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – In view of the brutal impact of an unexpected pandemic and for which the scientific community had little knowledge of immediate implementation, Member States have put close and containment responses on the ground.  These responses have gradually taken on degrees of coordination within the European Union, in particular in terms of information sharing and the search for solutions and equipment, of which the joint reserve of potential vaccines is a striking example. We need to go further.  The resolution under discussion identifies key areas where Member States' action has to be coordinated, both in terms of health practices and protocols, as well as in the area of restoring supply chains of goods and services within the framework of the single market, both in simplifying public procurement for the purpose of containing the pandemic, and also in the progressive restoration of the conditions for the free movement of persons.  We live in an exceptional situation, which required and requires exceptional answers. Responses that will be all the more effective the more coordinated they are in the assessment and communication of risks, in the sharing of information and in the protection of the founding freedoms of the European Union.
